question: Pan-Slavism in the late 19c sought to unite all of the following into a single entity EXCEPT?:
option: Poland.
Bulgaria.
Germany.
Russia.
the Czechs.
answer: Germany.

question: The disestablishment of the Church of Ireland and the passage of laws to protect the Irish tenant farmer occurred during the first ministry of?:
option: Benjamin Disraeli.
Herbert Spenser.
Lloyd George.
William Glastone.
Lord Palmerston.
answer: William Glastone.

question: Bismarck\'s  Kulturkampf  represented an effort to?:
option: undermine the influence of the socialists in Germany.
point out to Europeans the true nature of the so-called Yellow Peril.
strengthen anti-French feelings in Germany on the eve of the Franco-Prussian War.
halt the spread of Pan-Slavism in the Balkans.
weaken the political influence of the Catholic Church in Germany.
answer: weaken the political influence of the Catholic Church in Germany.

question: The unification of Italy was primarily due to?:
option: the activist of the Carbonari.
the success of Cavour and Garibaldi together with the French defeat in the Franco-Prussian War.
the activities of nationalists who wished to return to the glories of the Roman Empire.
Prussian pressure on Austria to cede Venetia to Italy.
religious zealots seeking to develop a papal theocracy in Italy.
answer: the success of Cavour and Garibaldi together with the French defeat in the Franco-Prussian War.

question: Proponents of nationalism in the mid-19c espoused?:
option: adopting a common European language.
universal human rights.
the creation of utopian socialist communes throughout Western Europe.
free trade to promote industrial development.
the idea that different peoples had distinct historical missions.
answer: the idea that different peoples had distinct historical missions.

question: The  Risorgimento  was the name of?:
option: the emergence of a prosperous Europe from the ashes of World War II.
the movement to unify Italy.
the high cultural achievements of the Italian Renaissance.
Napoleonic rule in Italy.
the movement to unify Germany.
answer: the movement to unify Italy.

question: Count Camillo Cavour hoped to unify Italy by means of?:
option: conquest of the Papal States and the Kingdom of Naples.
popular revolts against foreign rulers.
a military alliance with France against Austria.
a democratic plebiscite in all Italian-speaking areas.
a military alliance with Prussia against France.
answer: a military alliance with France against Austria.

question: The primary goal of Bismarck\'s foreign policy was?:
option: maintain the diplomatic isolation of France.
prepare for war with Britain.
expand the frontiers of the German Empire.
advance into the Balkans.
prepare for a colonial empire.
answer: maintain the diplomatic isolation of France.

question: The Catholic Emancipation Act allowed Roman Catholics in England?:
option: complete freedom of worship.
exemption from income taxes.
to attend Oxford and Cambridge.
to hold public office.
to build larger churches.
answer: to hold public office.

question: Under the terms of the Act of Union of 1801?:
option: Ireland lost its own legislature and instead sent representatives to London.
Ireland was granted the right to establish its own legislative body.
Catholics were allowed to sit in Parliament.
Protestant areas were separated from the rest of Ireland.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: Ireland lost its own legislature and instead sent representatives to London.

question: The Compromise of 1867 transformed the Habsburg Empire into?:
option: four separative administrative units.
a confederation of Slavic states.
a republic.
a dependency of Germany.
a Dual Monarchy.
answer: a Dual Monarchy.

question: Which was the most prominent obstacle to the unification of both Germany and Italy?:
option: privileged classes of each country.
Russian nationalism.
the Papacy.
Austria.
Napoleon III.
answer: Austria.

question: Prussia : German unification :: _____ : Italian unification.
option: Ventian Republic.
Piedmont-Sardinia.
Rome.
the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
Montenegro.
answer: Piedmont-Sardinia.

question: By the Treaty of Frankfurt, France?:
option: had to pay a large indemnity to Italy.
was required to abandon the Third Empire.
lost Alsace-Lorraine to Germany.
had to pay the Pope one million Francs in war damages.
received Trieste, Nice, and Savoy.
answer: lost Alsace-Lorraine to Germany.

question: The Crimean War helped to bring about all of the following EXCEPT the?:
option: rapid spread of socialism in France.
freeing of the serfs in Russia.
focusing of international attention on the Italian question.
growth of nationalism in Rumania.
reform of the British army.
answer: rapid spread of socialism in France.

question: The long-term goal of the Paris Commune was the?:
option: creation of a workers\' republic.
institution of a Marxist state.
destruction of the National Assembly.
creation of Paris as an autonomous commune separate from France.
institution of a new National Assembly for France.
answer: creation of Paris as an autonomous commune separate from France.

question: The term  realpolitik  applies to Bismarck\'s?:
option: realistic support of the liberal factions in the Prussian Parliament.
use of subterfuge, deceit, and military force to accomplish unification and to implement other policies.
support of Pan-Germanism.
support of Pan-Germanism.
admiration of Cavour\'s constitutional reforms in Italy.
answer: use of subterfuge, deceit, and military force to accomplish unification and to implement other policies.

question: After the publication of Theodor Herzl\'s book  The Jewish State ?:
option: Jews began to immigrate to the United States.
a Zionist Congress proclaimed its aim to create that state in Palestine.
the Ottoman Empire declared that there could be no Jewish immigration.
the Ottoman Empire declared that there could be no Jewish immigration.
a Zionist Congress proclaimed its aim to create that state in Palestine.
answer: a Zionist Congress proclaimed its aim to create that state in Palestine.

question: The Concert of Europe was shattered as a result of?:
option: the events of the Crimean War.
German unificaiton.
the Danish War.
the Franco-Prussian War.
Italian unification.
answer: the events of the Crimean War.

question: The nationalists of the first half of the nineteenth century were often?:
option: conservatives waving the flag of hard-line politics.
radicals who called for working-class revolution.
liberals attempting to overthrow tyrannical regimes.
members of the Old Regime.
romantics who valued the vernacular and folklore.
answer: liberals attempting to overthrow tyrannical regimes.

question: Changes affecting women in Western Europe since the 1950s include?:
option: greater participation in the labor force.
the achievement of wage equality with men.
a reduction in life expectancy.
increasing family size.
declining opportunities in higher education.
answer: greater participation in the labor force.

question: The surrealistic movement in modern abstract art is based upon the theme of?:
option: an internal vision of external objects.
providing a mathematical equation to balance the work.
portraying the subconcious and irrational in the artists work.
the use of geometrical forms to portray time and space.
a \'stream of conciousness\' development upon the artistic canvas.
answer: portraying the subconcious and irrational in the artists work.

question: The French writer Simone de Beauvoir?:
option: became a radical when she was refused admission to the Sorbonne.
provided European women an intellectual framework for their feminism.
played a pivotal role in the founding the National Organization for Women.
became a radical when she was refused employment as a teacher.
collaborated with American Betty Friedan on The Feminine Mystique.
answer: provided European women an intellectual framework for their feminism.

question: Which of the following statements about immigration to Western Europe since 1960 is NOT accurate?:
option: immigrants from poor countries were recruited to do poorly paid jobs in wealthier countries.
the admission of former colonies to the European Communist facilitated immigration.
immigration created significant Muslim communities in several Western European countries.
anti-immigrant movements became a significant political force in many Western European countries.
immigrant communities in Western European countries became targets for violent attacks.
answer: the admission of former colonies to the European Communist facilitated immigration.

question: Existentialism?:
option: saw human beings as morally corrupt.
tended to dwell on the perfection of mankind.
agreed that mankind was in a state of decline.
saw human beings as condemned to be free because of a rejection of societal customs.
stressed the idea that the separation of human experience into its component parts was the proper path to understanding.
answer: saw human beings as condemned to be free because of a rejection of societal customs.

question: The influential Annales school of historical thinking, developed in France, focuses on?:
option: the role of the "ruling classes" in directing society.
a microscopic examination of the immediate causes of events.
politics and a careful narrative of events.
the influence of the modern business corporation in politics.
long-term elements in historical change such as population, economy, climate and natural resources.
answer: long-term elements in historical change such as population, economy, climate and natural resources.

question: Which group has seen its importance in European politics increase since the 1970s?:
option: Eurocommunists.
environmentalists.
religious fundamentalists.
trade union parties.
socialists and communists.
answer: environmentalists.

question: This theologian urged each individual to seek God alone without relying on organized religion?:'
option: Soren Kierkegaard.
Bruno Bauer.
Oscar Schindler.
Joseph Smith.
Friedrich Nietzsche.
answer: Soren Kierkegaard.

question: A characteristic of Late Modernism was?:
option: an undaunting optimism.
a commitment to a fixed set of standards in art.
appropriation of images of mass culture.
function follows form.
a sense of saving Western civilization from itsef.
answer: a sense of saving Western civilization from itsef.

question: All of the following were 20c art movements EXCEPT?:
option: Bauhaus.
Dadaism.
Impressionism.
Cubism.
Expressionism.
answer: Impressionism.

question: Louis XIV supported all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: the building of the Palace of Versailles.
cooperation with the Estates-General.
art and culture.
the policies of Cardinal Richelieu.
the theory of divine right of kings.
answer: cooperation with the Estates-General.

question: The  corvee ?:
option: was involuntary forced labor imposed on French peasants.
was a tax assigned exclusively to French nobles that required them to pay their serf\'s feudal dues.
was a special, annual tax exemption granted to French nobles.
was a tool that improved the annual plowing of soil intended for agricultural use.
was the annual tax increase levied against nobles in France.
answer: was involuntary forced labor imposed on French peasants.

question: The English political philosopher, Thomas Hobbes, held that?:
option: only French kings ruled by divine right.
only in England was a limited, constitutional monarchy possible.
mankind is inherently good and requires no formal government.
Parliament ruled by divine right.
the power of the ruler was absolute but derived from an implicit contract with the governed.
answer: the power of the ruler was absolute but derived from an implicit contract with the governed.

question: Peter the Great\'s "Europeanization" of Russia consisted primarily of?:
option: establishing a Senate to debate progressive legislation.
giving Russian women equal political if not social rights to Russian men.
importing Western technocrats and technology to his country.
requiring his people to shave their beards and dress like Englishmen.
constitutional government and democratic government.
answer: importing Western technocrats and technology to his country.

question: Between the 16c and 17c, peasants in Poland, Bohemia, Hungary, and Russia?:
option: enjoyed more prosperity and independence.
were losing their rights and freedoms.
escaped from the corvee.
were granted democratic control over village life.
migrated to the West in massive numbers.
answer: were granted democratic control over village life.

question: The guiding force behind Cardinal Richelieu\'s domestic policies was?:
option: reform of the church.
a belief in decentralization.
the subordination of all groups and institutions to the monarchy.
the sovereignty of the people.
hostility to the Huguenots.
answer: the subordination of all groups and institutions to the monarchy.

question: In what ways was political life in the Netherlands unique in Europe in the 17c and 18c?:
option: the Netherlands was a republic with a decentralized government.
the Netherlands established the first parliamentary system of government.
political life in the Netherlands was dictated by the rules of a strict theocracy.
the Netherlands enjoyed a strongly centralized government.
the Netherlands was ruled by a powerful monarchy.
answer: the Netherlands was a republic with a decentralized government.

question: A significant feature of English society in the 16c and 17c was the?:
option: resurgence of Roman Catholicism.
declining popularity of "reformed" religions.
economic decline of the business classes.
increasing importance of monasticism.
growing wealth of the country genrty and middle-class businessmen.
answer: growing wealth of the country genrty and middle-class businessmen.

question: Colbert\'s contributions to the economy of France included all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: establishing new industries and colonial ventures.
creating a national bank.
improving the transportation and communication systems within France.
setting up tariffs to protect French industry.
creating a powerful merchant marine to transport French goods.
answer: creating a national bank.

question: The overall practical purpose of the court of Versailles was to?:
option: serve as Louis XIV\'s residence from which to survey Paris.
act as a reception hall for state affairs.
exclude the high nobility and royal princes from real power.
act as an art museum for the people of Paris.
give Louis XIV a life of privacy away from spies.
answer: exclude the high nobility and royal princes from real power.

question: During the English Revolution, the Levellers advocated the idea that?:
option: all private property should be abolished.
the economic playing field needed to be leveled to allow for greater opportunities for the poor.
the monarchy had to be restored.
all men should have the vote regardless of whether they own property.
there was a constract between the government and the people.
answer: all men should have the vote regardless of whether they own property.

question: The cabinet system in England is based upon the view that government leadership must?:
option: be divided into separate branches.
include the lower classes.
be elected to and supported by a majority of Parliament.
be representative of all political parties.
include two parties.
answer: be elected to and supported by a majority of Parliament.

question: Jacques Bossuet was the seventeenth century\'s most articulate?:
option: Catholic theologian on matters of prayer and personal devotion.
proponent of limited monarchy and constitutional government.
financial adviser to Louis XIV.
French Huguenot lawyer in cases involving religious freedom.
advocate of the absolute, divinely ordained right of kings.
answer: advocate of the absolute, divinely ordained right of kings.

question: Which of the following exerted the most influence on Italy in the eighteenth century?:
option: Dutch.
Austrians.
Spanish.
Turks.
English.
answer: Austrians.

question: The War of the Spanish Succession began when Charles II of Spain left his territories to?:
option: the French heir.
his son.
the Spanish heir.
the archduke of Austria.
Eugene of Savoy.
answer: the French heir.

question: Ivan III was responsible for the?:
option: conversion of Russia to Roman Catholicism.
military campaigns that freed much of Russia from the Mongols.
creation of the Eastern Orthodox Church in Russia.
policies of Westernization that required changes in dress among the Russian elite.
abolition of serfdom in Russia.
answer: military campaigns that freed much of Russia from the Mongols.

question: Which of the following was the most significant factor in the rise of national states in western Europe?:
option: the end of serfdom.
the acquiring of colonies in the New World.
the rise of the feudal nobility.
the need for protection from barbarian invasions.
the rise and support of the middle class.
answer: the rise and support of the middle class.

question: The Siege of Vienna in 1683 was undertaken by?:
option: the Hungarians under Prince Romanov.
the Venetians.
Frederick William of Prussia.
the Turks.
the Bohemians.
answer: the Turks.

question: Peter the Great\'s reforms included?:
option: requiring the Russian nobility to wear Western clothing and speaking French at court.
a lessening of the burdens of serfdom for Russian peasants.
an elimination of the merit-system bureaucracy.
the abolition of serfdom.
the creation of an independent parliament.
answer: requiring the Russian nobility to wear Western clothing and speaking French at court.

question: During the 16th century the main reason for the increase in power of the English monarch was the?:
option: Glorious Revolution.
ability of the Stuart rulers.
increased position of the nobility.
ability of the Tudor monarchs.
marriage of Queen Mary to Philip II of Spain.
answer: ability of the Tudor monarchs.

question: In 1640 Charles I called Parliament into session because he?:
option: needed money to pursue his war against France.
became a supporter of democratic principles.
wanted to change his religion.
wanted a declaration of war against Spain.
needed money to suppress a rebellion in Scotland.
answer: needed money to suppress a rebellion in Scotland.

question: In the 18c, the principal economic activity of the Netherlands was?:
option: cloth manufacturing.
banking and finance.
tulip cultivation.
maritime commerce.
agricultural production.
answer: banking and finance.

question: Although different in their sources of power, the governments of 18c Great Britain and France had which of the following characteristics in common?:
option: both nations were constitutional monarchies.
the power to levy taxes was controlled by the monarch in both nations.
by the mid-1700s, the Prime Minister had become the real power in British and French politics, not the monarchy.
neither nation had wide class differences.
both nations had a small elite of landowning aristocrats who were considered the "natural" ruling class with power and influence in the government.
answer: both nations had a small elite of landowning aristocrats who were considered the "natural" ruling class with power and influence in the government.

question: An immediate effect of the Glorious Revolution in England was?:
option: the return of the Tudors as rulers of England.
universal manhood suffrage.
the persecution of members of the Anglican Church.
the decline of England as a colonial power.
the supremacy of Parliament over the monarchy.
answer: the supremacy of Parliament over the monarchy.

question: What did John Locke mean by the term  tabula rasa ?:
option: the \'unchangeable tablet\' on which the largest amount of an individual\'s future has already been written.
instinctual behavior.
the \'gene pool\' passed from parent to child.
the \'blank slate\' that is the human mind at birth.
the hierarchy of races in the world--with Europeans occupying the highest position.the hierarchy of races in the world--with Europeans occupying the highest position.
answer: the \'blank slate\' that is the human mind at birth.

question: Thomas Hobbes and John Locke disagreed over the theory that?:
option: man once lived in a state of nature without government.
kings rule by divine right.
the only alternative to social chaos is absolute monarchy.
man\'s mind is at birth a  tabula rasa.
all men are endowed with certain unalienable rights.
answer: the only alternative to social chaos is absolute monarchy.

question: The Pragmatic Sanction (1713) stated that the Hapsburg possessions?:
option: could never be passed to a female heir
could never be divided.
were always to remain within the Austrian branch of the fa
were to be inherited by Louis XIV\'s grandson after the death of Charles VI.
could follow whichever religion the majority of people in each area favored.
c British nobility differed from 18c French nobility in that?:
the French nobility paid direct taxes and had no significant legal privileges.
the English aristocracy paid no taxes while the French nobility were burdened with the taille and the gabelle.
the French nobility did not enjoy hereditary privileges as did the English.
the English aristocracy accepted the social and political responsibilities of their position and participated more directly in running their government.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: the English aristocracy accepted the social and political responsibilities of their position and participated more directly in running their government.

question: In the 18c, Europe\'s largest city was?:
option: Berlin.
London.
Vienna.
Paris.
Rome.
answer: London.

question: Peasant life in 18c Europe was characterized by?:
option: close and cordial relations with local landlords.
new opportunities for all rural children to obtain an elementary education.
a willingness to try experimental farming techniques.
the confining of women to household activities.
vulnerability to rising taxes and rents.
answer: vulnerability to rising taxes and rents.

question: The artistic movement that replaced the Baroque during the Enlightenment was?:
option: Romanesque.
Neo-Classical.
Empirical.
Rococo.
Mannerism.
answer: Rococo.

question: In 18c England, the greatest threat to the economic security of small farmers was?:
option: the Enclosure Movement.
laissez-faire  economic policies.
the political influence of the Church of England.
economic competition from French farmers.
the increasing use of agricultural land by industrial interests.
answer: the Enclosure Movement.

question: Economic and social life among the mass of people under the  Ancien Regime  of the 18c still primarily focused around?:
option: parliamentary elections.
the harvest.
the London Stock Exchange.
military service.
colonial trade.
answer: the harvest.

question: The European lower classes reacted to the Enlightenment by?:
option: supporting their rulers against the nobles and clergy.
violently rebelling against their governments.
seeking comfort in grass-roots religious revival movements.
more of them turning to crime.
immersing themselves in spiritual and philosophical study.
answer: seeking comfort in grass-roots religious revival movements.

question: Which of the following statements best describes the attitude toward children in the first part of the 18c?:
option: they were protected and cherished.
they were never disciplined.
they were treated as they were--children living in a child\'s world.
they were ignored, often brutalized, and often unloved.
they were seen as property.
answer: they were ignored, often brutalized, and often unloved.

question: Who were the first to initiate a political campaign to abolish slavery?:
option: French  philosophes .
Quakers and Baptists.
the British navy.
the Brazilian government.
Dutch merchants.
answer: Quakers and Baptists.

question: Which of the following statements best applies to Europe\'s social order in the 18c?:
option: it differed from the Middle Ages in that wealth was the sole determining factor in a person\'s social standing.
the nobility was homogeneous and served the same social function throughout Europe.
peasants and nobles grew closer socially in eastern Europe, where serfdom was eradicated.
most of 18c European universities allowed students from the lower and middle classes to enroll and attend some classes.
peasants were still hindered by a variety of feudal services and fees imposed by the powerful aristocracy.
answer: peasants were still hindered by a variety of feudal services and fees imposed by the powerful aristocracy.

question: European efforts to deal with crime after 1700?:
option: rejected imprisonment because of its high unit cost.
never employed the use of torture.
increased the severity of punishment for theft.
employed public displays of punishment for the purpose of deterrence.
reserved the use of capital punishment exclusively for criminal cases.
answer: employed public displays of punishment for the purpose of deterrence.

question: During the  Ancien Regime , European Jews?:
option: were separated from non-Jews in districts called ghettos.
were permitted equal access to social and economic opportunities in western European countries.
were living primarily in western Europe.
enjoyed all of the rights and privileges of other subjects.
were pro-monarchy.
answer: were separated from non-Jews in districts called ghettos.

question: Which post-World War II leader is INCORRECTLY paired with the country he led?:
option: MacMillan and England.
Tito and Italy.
Khrushchev and the U.S.S.R.
DeGaulle and France.
Adenauer and West Germany.
answer: Tito and Italy.

question: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization was formed in response to?:
option: the events surrounding the Berlin Blockade.
the communist victory in the civil war in China.
Soviet refusal of Marshall Plan assistance for all of eastern Europe.
the Soviet formation of the Warsaw Pact.
Soviet detonation of its first nuclear device.
answer: the events surrounding the Berlin Blockade.

question: The collapse of the Fourth Republic and the rise of the Fifth Republic occurred in France over?:
option: fear of renewed war with Germany.
economic collapse.
breakdown in relations with the United States.
socialist welfare policy.
the independence movement in Algeria.
answer: the independence movement in Algeria.

question: Euro-communism is?:
option: the term used to describe the general program of French communism during the 1950s.
a program devised by Italian Communists to make their policies more compatible with the needs of Western Europe.
a literary and artistic movement of the late 1950s and early 1960s which stressed the importance of the individual worker in European society.
the hope of Eastern European Communists to maintain some power and credibility after the changes of 1989-1990.
the Soviet policy to expand Soviet hegemony following 1945.
answer: a program devised by Italian Communists to make their policies more compatible with the needs of Western Europe.

question: The decision of the East Germans to erect a wall dividing East and West Berlin?:
option: was made in 1961 to halt the flow of refugees from East Germany.
recognized that Berlin was a city of spies whose movements needed to be restricted.
to prevent the infiltration of western spies into East Berlin.
occurred immediately following the outbreak of the Korean War to symbolize Communist disenchantment with the West.
was intended to illustrate that East Germany would never again unite with West Germany.
answer: was made in 1961 to halt the flow of refugees from East Germany.

question: Which communist country successfully asserted independence from Moscow\'s control soon after the end of the Second World War?:
option: Bulgaria.
Poland.
Yugoslavia.
Czechoslovakia.
Hungary.
answer: Yugoslavia.

question: Which of the following was NOT a result of the Polish and Hungarian disturbances in 1956?:
option: they demonstrated the hollowness of American political rhetoric.
they demonstrated that Austrian neutrality would not be imitated in Eastern Europe.
they demonstrated the limitations of independence within the Soviet bloc.
they exposed the lack of military will on the part of the West to really help freedom-fighters in Eastern Europe.
they brought an end to independent action in the Soviet bloc.
answer: they brought an end to independent action in the Soviet bloc.

question: Under Clement Atlee\'s administration, the government?:
option: undertook a major housing program.
strongly supported British trade unions.
assumed ownership of certain major industries.
instituted a major program of welfare legislation.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: One of the most important causes of the Cold War between the USSR and the United States after World War II was?:
option: refusal of the Western powers to give the USSR a role in post war Germany.
rivalries with the Eastern bloc.
ideological conflicts.
border disputes in Scandinavia.
Russian occupation of northern Italy.
answer: ideological conflicts.

question: The "Prague Spring" refers to?:
option: a new agricultural program introduced by the Czechoslovak Communist leadership that led to the "Green Revolution" in Eastern Europe.
the unsuccessful liberalization program attempted by Alexander Dubcek.
a great drought in 1968.
a cultural flowering of Czech literature in the immediate post-World War II era.
the increase in the number of Czech troops committed to the Warsaw Pact.
answer: the unsuccessful liberalization program attempted by Alexander Dubcek.

question: The most serious fear shared by Soviet and Western statesmen after World War II was?:
option: political deadlocks in the United Nations.
success of communism in Italy.
formation of the Common Market.
revival of a strong military state in Germany.
the failure of democracy in Czechoslovakia.
answer: revival of a strong military state in Germany.

question: Which BEST characterizes West Germany\'s  Ostpolitik ?:
option: the refusal to have economic ties with any nation that extended diplomatic recognition to East Germany.
withdrawal from the Common Market in favor of economic integration in Eastern Europe.
West German rearmament and participation in NATO.
the establishment of better relations with Eastern Europe.
West Germany\'s withdrawal from the United Nations in 1965.
answer: the establishment of better relations with Eastern Europe.

question: The most serious post-World War II split in the Communist Bloc was?:
option: the rupture of the Soviet-Chinese alliance.
the defection of Marshall Tito.
Cuba\'s objections to Soviet policy.
the Ceascescu regime in Rumania.
the loss of Albania.
answer: the rupture of the Soviet-Chinese alliance.

question: Between the death of Stalin and the rise of Gorbachev, the Soviet Union?:
option: dismantled the KGB.
solved its agricultural problems.
experienced some liberalization along with increasing economic decline.
renounced repression of revolt in the satellites.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: experienced some liberalization along with increasing economic decline.

question: The Marshall Plan?:
option: would supply military assistance to any country threatened by communism.
excluded the Soviet Union and eastern Europe from participation.
was viewed by Western Europe as Capitalist imperialism.
was not considered a success.
intended to rebuild European prosperity and stability.
answer: intended to rebuild European prosperity and stability.

question: One of de Gaulle\'s important achievements was to?:
option: resolve the Algerian crisis by giving the Algerians the right to vote in the French parliament.
end political instability in France.
take the lead in the expansion of the Common Market by negotiating the membership of Britain.
increase the value of the French franc in relationship to the U. S. dollar.
take the lead in promoting the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons.
answer: end political instability in France.

question: One of Gorbachev\'s key policies was  perestroika , which meant?:
option: drastic restructuring of the centrally planned command economy.
the rapid creation of a free market economy.
political rule by a three-person directorate.
abolishing the KGB and introducing free political elections.
at first, drastic political restructuring; later Gorbachev believed such restructuring could be applied to society as a whole.
answer: drastic restructuring of the centrally planned command economy.

question: During the Khrushchev era (1956-64) the Soviet Union?:
option: retreated from some Stalinist practices.
enjoyed great expansion in agricultural production.
sought to join NATO.
rapidly created a consumer economy.
became democratic.
answer: retreated from some Stalinist practices.

question: The most innovative Soviet postwar scientific achievement was its?:
option: construction of the world\'s largest dam on the Volga River.
construction of the massive  gulag  network.
design and production of high-quality fighter planes.
launch of the world\'s first unmanned space satellite.
explosion of atomic and hydrogen bombs.
answer: launch of the world\'s first unmanned space satellite.

question: Khrushchev solidified his position as Stalin\'s successor with a speech to the Twentieth Party Congress in 1956 that he?:
option: further glorified Stalin by revealing some of his additional achievements.
started a campaign to eliminate Stalin\'s influence by revealing his atrocities and reducing his prestige.
supported the Egyptian side in the Suez Crisis.
promised a rapid end to communist control of Eastern Europe and China.
announced an end to the Cold War and the signing of a military alliance with America.
answer: started a campaign to eliminate Stalin\'s influence by revealing his atrocities and reducing his prestige.

question: In reality, the policy of  detente  between the Soviet Union and the United States?:
option: encouraged the eruption of new conflicts in the Third World.
only worsened relations and increased tensions among the superpowers.
was bitterly opposed by both Nixon and Brezhnev.
defined the process by which the superpowers agreed to formalize their postwar dominance.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: defined the process by which the superpowers agreed to formalize their postwar dominance.

question: As President of France, Charles de Gaulle\'s policy toward the Cold War was to?:
option: remain independent of both superpowers.
make France the leading member of NATO.
follow the American lead throughout.
form a close military and economic alliance with Britain and West Germany.
closely align France with the Warsaw Pact nations.
answer: remain independent of both superpowers.

question: The European Economic Community had its origins in an agreement about?:
option: agricultural production.
coal and steel production.
railway operation.
river navigation.
response to the report of the Club of Rome.
answer: coal and steel production.

question: All of the following are reactions to the development of nuclear weapons EXCEPT?:
option: fear of M.A.D., "mutually assured destruction," which led to the suspension of nuclear war.
the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
the decline in the number of guerilla wars with their dependence on traditional weapons.
modern war technology, which was confined to countries that can afford it, often with traumatic consequences to the national economies.
the space exploration programs of the Soviet Union and the United States, which inclded a consideration of the use of weapons technology.
answer: the decline in the number of guerilla wars with their dependence on traditional weapons.

question: The outbreak of student revolts in Western Europe the late 1960s was inspired by?:
option: the war in Vietnam.
overcrowded classrooms and lack of professorial attention.
discontent with materialism.
poor job prospects for new graduates.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: The 1960 US-USSR summit meeting was wrecked when?:
option: the United States put a quarantine around Cuba.
the Soviets crushed an uprising in Hungary.
the United States discovered a number of Soviet spies in its midst.
the Soviets erected the Berlin Wall.
a U-2 spy plane was shot down over Russia.
answer: a U-2 spy plane was shot down over Russia.

question: Margaret Thatcher\'s popularity rose when she successfully prevented?:
option: Japan from taking Taiwan.
Argentina from taking the Falklands.
China from taking Hong Kong.
India from taking Burma.
Mexico from taking El Salvador.
answer: Argentina from taking the Falklands.

question: Thatcherism stressed all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: nationalization of industries.
high interest rates.
destroying the power of labor unions.
sharp tax cuts.
reduced government spending.
answer: nationalization of industries.

question: The Solidarity movement in Poland, which ultimately toppled the communist regime, was helped by what other Polish institution?:
option: the Polish parliament.
the peasantry.
the army.
the Catholic Church.
the dissident communist party members.
answer: the Catholic Church.

question: The first European country to enter into direct trade with the Far East and establish colonies there was?:
option: Spain.
France.
Britain.
Portugal.
Holland.
answer: Portugal.

question: The Spanish empire in America was characterized by?:
option: its enormous African slave population.
a large  creole  class of higher-level colonial government officials.
the relatively large white population.
the exhaustion of the great silver mines of Mexico and Peru by 1550.
the introduction of a manorial-like system, the  encomienda.
answer: the introduction of a manorial-like system, the  encomienda.

question: Which of the following groups generally benefited from the inflation of the sixteenth century?:
option: landowning nobility.
merchants.
peasants.
colonial officials.
all of these groups benefited.
answer: merchants.

question: Why did the English, Dutch, and French governments fail to begin colonization of the Americas and direct trade with the Orient until more than 100 years after Columbus discovered America?:
option: their geographical positions put them at a disadvantage for trans-oceanic movement.
the northern countries lacked suitable ships and the advanced technology to make long voyages.
domestic troubles and religious controversies delayed organized action.
Western European bankers refused to loan monarchs money for such ventures.
the northerners were slow to abandon their traditional Mediterranean trade routes.
answer: domestic troubles and religious controversies delayed organized action.

question: Spain\'s expansion in the Americas was made particularly easy by?:
option: the absence of prior civilizations among the native peoples.
the impact of imported diseases on the Indian population.
Spain\'s leadership in European banking and commerce.
the belief that Europe had much to learn from the religions and customs of other peoples.
competition between Protestant and Catholic missionaries sent out by Spain.
answer: the impact of imported diseases on the Indian population.

question: The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) granted Portugal the eastern trade route to the Indies as well as Brazil; lands to the west of Brazil were given to?:
option: England.
Italy.
Spain.
France.
Holland.
answer: Spain.

question: The technological innovations in maritime technology by the 1500s were important because?:
option: they made it cheaper to sail.
they increased the number of slaved needed to sail the ships.
they required literate sailors.
they made it possible for Europeans to sail anywhere.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: they made it possible for Europeans to sail anywhere.

question: By the 16th century the center of commercial activity had shifted from the Mediterranean to the?:
option: Atlantic Ocean.
Red Sea.
Indian Ocean.
Baltic Sea.
North Sea.
answer: Atlantic Ocean.

question: Encomiendas  in the Spanish New World were?:
option: local councils of aristocratics who assisted the viceroys.
grants permitting owners to take income or labor from land and its inhabitants.
special schools set up in the Franciscan missions to educate native Indian children.
elected colonial assemblies.
local Indian chiefs who collected taxes and administered Spanish laws.
answer: grants permitting owners to take income or labor from land and its inhabitants.

question: Scarcity of labor in the Americas led the Spanish and Portuguese colonizers to?:
option: establish a wage-earning system for the Indians.
institute policies that protected the Indians.
import slaves from Africa.
encourage English and Dutch settlers to emigrate to the New World.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: import slaves from Africa.

question: The Mediterranean carrying trade in the 14c and 15c was in the hands of?:
option: the Marseilles merchants.
Venice.
Constantinople.
Greek city-states.
Florence.
answer: Venice.

question: Portuguese exploration of the African coast was inspired and supported by?:
option: Bartholomew Diaz.
Emperor Charles V.
Ferdinand and Isabella.
John Cabot.
Prince Henry the Navigator.
answer: Prince Henry the Navigator.

question: The major cause of the growing weakness of Spain and Portugal after 1600 was the?:
option: drain placed on Iberia\'s finances by colonization efforts in the Americas.
failure to find productive investments with profits from New World colonies.
invasion of the Iberian Peninsula by France.
deflationary impact of bullion imports.
successful opposition by Amerindians and Africans.
answer: failure to find productive investments with profits from New World colonies.

question: All of the following helped cause the Age of European Exploration EXCEPT?:
option: technological advances making long sea voyages possible.
the desire to spread Christianity to native Indian peoples.
the Mughals\' continued encroachment into Central Europe.
European demand for eastern spices.
Ottoman expansion threatening access to the goods of the East.
answer: the Mughals\' continued encroachment into Central Europe.

question: In 1571 the Spanish and Turkish control of the Mediterranean at the battle of?:
option: the Dardanelles.
Gibraltar.
Trafalgar.
Lepanto.
Haifa.
answer: Lepanto.

question: Which BEST explains the decline of Spanish power in the 17c?:
option: foolish monarchs and an uncertain flow of treasure from the New World.
an unproductive and wasteful nobility.
foreign policy reversals.
the decline of the importation of raw materials.
the Catholic Church no longer supported the merchant class in Spain.
answer: foolish monarchs and an uncertain flow of treasure from the New World.

question: Why did the initiative in early conquest and exploration pass to northern European nations in the later 16c?:
option: Spain and Portugal were defeated in a critical war with the Ottoman Empire.
the Dutch and the British improved the design of oceanic vessels, producing faster ships than their Catholic rivals.
famine and disease disastrously reduced the population of the Iberian Peninsula after 1588.
the French and Danish business infrastructures were more developed than in the Iberian Peninsula countries.
the Spanish defeat of the English Armada cut England off from further advance in Europe and forced English attention to foreign conquest.
answer: the Dutch and the British improved the design of oceanic vessels, producing faster ships than their Catholic rivals.

question: At its height (ca. 1580), the Spanish empire of Philip II included all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: Milan.
the Free County of Burgundy.
Silesia.
Bohemia.
Portugal.
answer: Bohemia.

question: For England, the primary result of the 16c wars with Spain was that it?:
option: made her Europe\'s strongest power.
forced England to tolerate her Catholic minority.
resulted in the immediate death of its main colonial rival, Philip II of Spain.
bankrupted her treasury, forcing Elizabeth to become more and more dependent on parliament.
assured her national independence and promoted an intense national spirit.
answer: assured her national independence and promoted an intense national spirit.

question: Rousseau\'s conception of the General Will meant?:
option: representative democracy.
a vague common "interest" but not necessarily majority rule.
perhaps democracy but much more, probably a kind of totalitarian dictatorship.
the pressure of organized public opinion, which could be most successfully expressed through modernized parliamentary institutions.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: a vague common "interest" but not necessarily majority rule.

question: Voltaire\'s famous polemic slogan,  Crush the infamous thing! , referred to?:
option: royal despotism.
censorship laws.
political radicalism.
religious bigotry as supported by an organized clergy.
constitutional monarchy.
answer: religious bigotry as supported by an organized clergy.

question: In general, the 18c  philosophes  were?:
option: popularizers of the scientific and intellectual discoveries of the 17c.
a group of philosophers concerned with reexamining the ultimate questions of man\'s existence.
a group of learned Christian clerics who wished to modernize religion.
originators of a new philosophy based on reason and the concept of natural law.
people who were always the wealthiest members of 18c Western European society.
answer: popularizers of the scientific and intellectual discoveries of the 17c.

question: The best government, said which of the following men, is achieved by the separation of powers?:
option: Locke.
Voltaire.
Montesqiueu.
Diderot.
Hobbes.
answer: Montesqiueu.

question: Both Montesquieu and Voltaire?:
option: admired the Middle Ages.
supported some censorship on speech and religious beliefs.
rejected common law and preferred traditional Roman law codes.
preferred a rational, absolute central government.
admired English institutions.
answer: admired English institutions.

question: Which of the following was NOT a principle of Deism?:
option: God favors a rational morality.
science proves that God does not exist.
rewards and punishments are metted out in the afterlife.
nature has a rational order.
God is not interested in the everday lives of humans.
answer: science proves that God does not exist.

question: Thinkers of the Enlightenment considered humanity as?:
option: emotional believers in God.
bundles of feelings, animal urges, and fears.
a link in the rationally ordered chain of beings.
incapable of reason.
the only reason for a divinely inspired universe.
answer: a link in the rationally ordered chain of beings.

question: Enlightenment  philosophes  argued that women?:
option: were equal to men.
should be allowed to vote.
were biologically different from men, but were political equals to men.
have no innate knowledge.
and men were different and operated in separate spheres.
answer: and men were different and operated in separate spheres.

question: Maria Theresa can be labeled an "Enlightened Despot" because she?:
option: introduced religious toleration in the Habsburg Empire.
abolished political torture and persecution of different points of view.
eliminated the death penalty in the Habsburg Empire.
introduced many legal reforms in the Habsburg Empire.
invited political radicals to live in her palace in Vienna.
answer: introduced many legal reforms in the Habsburg Empire.

question: David Hume argued that human beings?:
option: did possess innate truths about God.
confirmed their innate understanding about God by reading the Scriptures.
did not have any certain knowlede at birth.
possessed both innate and learned truths about God.
were born like a  tabula rasa , upon which life experience would "write" its impressions.
answer: did not have any certain knowlede at birth.

question: For Rousseau, what was the main source of inequality and the chief cause of crime?:
option: marriage.
religion.
philosophical knowledge.
education.
private property.
answer: private property.

question: The most important contribution Catherine the Great made early in her reign was the?:
option: establishment of a legislative commission to review the laws of Russia.
abolition of serfdom and establishment of a progressive form of sharecropping.
peace pact she made with Sweden, thus ending 60 years of intermittent warfare.
elimination of Russian Orthodox churchment from state service.
initiation of a new poll tax to increase tax revenues needed for future wars.
answer: establishment of a legislative commission to review the laws of Russia.

question: All of the following are considered major factors that fostered the ideals of the Enlightenment EXCEPT?:
option: the stability and commercial prosperity of Great Britain after 1688.
the colonial worldview.
the Newtonian worldview.
the need for administrative and economic reform in France after the wars of Louis XIV.
the consolidation of a print culture.
answer: the colonial worldview.

question: Many 18c  philosophes  believed that governmental reform would be accomplished by?:
option: the introduction of democracy.
empowering the nobles at the expense of the kings.
benevolent absolutist monarchs.
revolution.
trusting the masses.
answer: benevolent absolutist monarchs.

question: The ideas of the Enlightenment challenged the long-term assumptions about sovereignty and instead proposed that?:
option: true government stems from religious authority.
governments are bound to the will of the people
the best form of government is a democracy.
all government is inherently unjust. Humans are better off living in a state of nature.
church and state should be entirely separate.
answer: governments are bound to the will of the people

question: Which of the following CANNOT be said of the 18c Enlightenment?:
option: the Newtonian Revolution of the previous century set it in motion.
it was based on the belief that unchangeable natural laws governed human society as well as the physical universe.
it supported the assumption that human reason could fathom the natural laws.
it reflected acceptance of social inequities and injustices as inevitable effects of the natural law
it was optimistic and progress-oriented.
answer: it reflected acceptance of social inequities and injustices as inevitable effects of the natural law

question: The Enlightenment?:
option: was based upon the assumption that science and reason can explain all things.
regarded human progress as an impossibility "in this best of all possible worlds."
was diametrically opposed to the Newtonian concept of natural law.
rejected the claims of modern science.
was widely attacked by the royalty and nobility of Europe.
answer: was based upon the assumption that science and reason can explain all things.

question: The recognized capital of the Enlightenment was?:
option: London.
Amsterdam.
Paris.
Vienna.
St. Petersburg
answer: Paris.

question: Rousseau\'s most important concept in  The Social Contract  was that?:
option: government must be based on the absolute authority of a divinely appointed monarch.
the main function of laws is to subdue man\'s evil nature.
governments exist by divine plan and to rebel against them is to rebel against God.
the monarchy is the outward expression of the "general will."
government must be based on voluntary participation by citizens, not simply by the accident of history or inheritance.
answer: government must be based on voluntary participation by citizens, not simply by the accident of history or inheritance.

question: Recent scholarship suggests that the enlightened despots of Europe?:
option: were more "enlightened" than "despotic."
represent a new type of monarchy that emerged in the eighteenth century.
were affected little by Enlightenment ideas.
had absolutely nothing to do with the philosophes or their ideas.
relished the opportunity to implement the ideas of the  philosophes .
answer: were affected little by Enlightenment ideas.

question: Recent challenges to the traditional explanation of the origins of the French Revolution have centered on the fact that the?:
option: Old Regime did not correspond to social reality.
nobility and upper bourgeoisie were not necessarily pitted against each other.
clergy played a liberal role in French society.
revolution broke out all over France, not just in Paris.
lower middle class was actually more reactionary than radical.
answer: nobility and upper bourgeoisie were not necessarily pitted against each other.

question: The principal French tax, the  taille , was paid by?:
option: every Frenchman.
the nobility only.
the peasantry almost exclusively.
parish priests.
the bourgeoisie only.
answer: the peasantry almost exclusively.

question: An English statesman whose criticism of the French Revolution and other writings have earned him a reputation as a spokesman for conservatism was?:
option: Charles Townshend.
George Grenville.
Sir Robert Blake.
William Pitt the Younger.
Edmund Burke.
answer: Edmund Burke.

question: All of the following are accurate statements about the French Revolution EXCEPT?:
option: France had a non-representative government before and after the French Revolution.
the Revolution destroyed the vestiges of manorialism.
the ideals of the French Revolution spread throughout Europe.
the Revolution failed to end the legal inequities between the classes.
the Revolution influenced French society to measure status by ability rather than by birth.
answer: the Revolution failed to end the legal inequities between the classes.

question: During the era of the French Revolution, the Thermidorean Reaction?:
option: terminated the Reign of Terror and led to the execution of Robespierre.
initiated the Reign of Terror.
resulted in the dissolution of the National Assembly.
was the direct cause for the rise of Napoleon.
witnessed the execution of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette.
answer: terminated the Reign of Terror and led to the execution of Robespierre.

question: During the Reign of Terror, the Committee of Public Safety sought to do all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: suppress independent  sans-culotte  activity.
protect the revolution from its domestic foes.
establish a separation between state and religion.
drive foreign armies out of France.
prevent runaway inflation.
answer: establish a separation between state and religion.

question: The legislators of the French Revolution enacted all of the following measures that affected women EXCEPT a law?:
option: permitting either party in a marriage to request a divorce.
giving women the right to control their own property.
forbidding the formation of political clubs for women.
permitting nuns to quit their vows.
granting the right to vote to women who owned a sufficient amount of property.
answer: granting the right to vote to women who owned a sufficient amount of property.

question: Which of the following was a result of the  Civil Constitution of the Clergy ?:
option: the clergy were given a privileged position in the Estates-General.
the church was made a department of the French state.
the clergy were condemned to execution during the Reign of Terror.
the office of bishop was abolished.
the church was made completely independent from the state.
answer: the church was made a department of the French state.

question: The National Assembly\'s efforts to reorganize the Catholic Church resulted in?:
option: deep division within both the country and the clergy.
the endorsement of the Revolution by the church.
an equitable redistribution of monastic lands among the peasants.
the War of the First Coalition.
the dismemberment of the French national church and closer ties being made with the papacy.
answer: deep division within both the country and the clergy.

question: The new Republican calendar of 1793?:
option: was based on the old Gregorian calendar that had gone out of use in the 16.
was kept until Napoleon\'s defeat in 1815.
was well received by most of the people.
was part of an effort at dechristianization.
named days and months after former kings.
answer: was part of an effort at dechristianization.

question: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen  guaranteed?:
option: universal manhood suffrage.
abolition of the monarchy.
free education.
no new taxes.
security of property.
answer: security of property.

question: The  cahiers de doleances  of 1789 generally demanded?:
option: the death of the king.
government reforms.
war with Austria.
an end to the use of the guillotine.
the overthrow of the Church.
answer: government reforms.

question: The greatest number of victims under "The Terror" (1793-1794) were from which social group?:
option: clergy.
nobility.
foreigners.
bourgeoisie.
peasants.
answer: peasants.

question: Which of the following was responsible for the convening of the Estates General in 1789?:
option: the storming of the Bastille.
peasant rejection of increased manorial dues.
royal abolition of guild restrictions.
the French government\'s near bankruptcy.
religious warfare between Huguenots and Catholics.
answer: the French government\'s near bankruptcy.

question: The French National Assembly was established by?:
option: leading  philosophes .
the aristocracy.
King Louis XVI.
the  sans-culottes .
the middle class of the Third Estate.
answer: the middle class of the Third Estate.

question: The seizure of the Bastille on July 14, 1789 was important because it?:
option: gave the  sans-cullotte  a strong fort.
released thousands of prisoners who joined the revolutionaries.
represented a successful attack on the tyranny of the Old Regime.
placed the royal family under the control of the Paris mobs.
brought Britain into the war against the French Republic.
answer: represented a successful attack on the tyranny of the Old Regime.

question: The  assignats  of the French Revolutionary era were?:
option: paper currency backed by church lands.
plots of land sold to peasants.
members of a moderate political party.
nobles who fled from France.
peasant revolts against the Republic.
answer: paper currency backed by church lands.

question: For the French peasants, the Revolution of 1789 meant?:
option: a general movement from the countryside to urban areas.
greater landownership.
few, if any, gains.
an end to forced conscription in the army.
significant political power.
answer: greater landownership.

question: Abbe Sieyes\'s answer to the question "What is the Third Estate?" was
option: a bunch of radicals.
those who adhered to liberalism.
the most useful component of French society.
the business and professional elite.
the community of artists and musicians.
answer: the most useful component of French society.

question: The term "Great Fear" refers to
option: the horiffic retreat of the French Army from Russia in 1812.
murder of thousands of enemies of the Revolution in the prisons.
panic in the countryside that fanned the flames of rebellion.
the fear of an English invasion of France.
Use of the guillotine during the Reign of Terror.
answer: panic in the countryside that fanned the flames of rebellion.

question: The men elected to represent the third estate in the Estates General were primarily?:
option: provincial nobles.
businessmen.
soldiers.
lawyers and government officials.
sans-culottes.
answer: lawyers and government officials.

question: Written in the midst of the French Revolution, the 1793 Constitution?:
option: was written by a group of revolutionaries known as the Directory.
was very similar to the 1790 version.
owed its existence solely to the American Declaration of Independence.
was a conservtive document that prepared the way for Napoleon\'s rise to power as emperor.
reflected the vision of Rousseau\'s social contract.
answer: reflected the vision of Rousseau\'s social contract.

question: The Committee of Public Safety was established to?:
option: negotiate a military alliance with England.
combat the dual threat of internal rebellion/counter-revolutionaries and foreign invasion.
provide the nation with a new, liberal monarchy.
negotiate the safe return of the French army from Prussia.
train a new generation of intendants who were more loyal to the bourgeoisie government in power in 1794.
answer: combat the dual threat of internal rebellion/counter-revolutionaries and foreign invasion.

question: Louis XVI responded to the Tennis Court Oath by?:
option: arresting the principal leaders of the National Assembly.
attempting to transfer the meetings of the estates to southern France.
promising to reform the national tax-collecting system.
ordering the National Guard to surround the National Assembly.
declaring the actions of the third estate illegal.
answer: declaring the actions of the third estate illegal.

question: Which of the following groups in France were most opposed to the Civil Constitution of the Clergy?:
option: deists.
bourgeoisie.
Jacobins.
peasants.
liberal aristocrats.
answer: peasants.

question: Lettres de cachet  were a means by which the French king could?:
option: arrange for a meeting with his mistress.
correspond informally with ministers of foreign nations.
imprison anyone without benefit of a trial.
execute criminals convicted of capital offenses.
transferred power from the bourgeoisie to the privileged orders in society.
answer: imprison anyone without benefit of a trial.

question: The political views of the Girondists were?:
option: more moderate than the view of other Jacobins.
sympathetic to a restored monarchy.
somewhat moderate, but very anti-Catholic.
the most radical of those in power.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: more moderate than the view of other Jacobins.

question: According to the rules of the French Constitution of 1791, "active citizens" were defined as?:
option: married men, with property and family.
men who paid annual taxes equal to three days of labor wages.
men who were landowners and had servants or employees under their care.
women and men who paid their taxes and could demonstrate an income.
men who could prove their aristocratic or noble status.
answer: men who paid annual taxes equal to three days of labor wages.

question: All of the following were reforms passed by the French National Assembly in reaction to earlier abuses EXCEPT?:
option: the Law of Suspects.
confiscation of Church property.
limitations on the power of the monarchy.
revocation of special privileges of the nobility.
ended papal authority over French clergy.
answer: the Law of Suspects.

question: The conservative government that came to power after the Thermidorean Reaction?:
option: supported the most radical ideas of the revolutionary era.
ordered that mobs caught intimidating legislatures be attacked by the army.
returned the Catholic faith to the position of state religion.
restricted free trade in an effort to replenish the state treasury.
restored social stability without sacrificing the ideals of 1789.
answer: restored social stability without sacrificing the ideals of 1789.

question: Industrialization in England resulted in all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: the elimination of social distinctions between the middle and working class.
the increased production of goods in all industries.
the reinvestment of profits from manufacturing.
the expansion of trade according to market demand.
new methods of production.
answer: the elimination of social distinctions between the middle and working class.

question: The British Ten Hours Act mainly concerned?:
option: British railroad workers.
the labor of women and children in British factores.
French radicals during the Revolution.
German dockworkers .
Slum dwellers in London.
answer: the labor of women and children in British factores.

question: A major cause of the Industrial Revolution was the?:
option: effort to eliminate child labor.
need for more manufactured goods for foreign trade.
desire for colonies.
increase in population.
racial ideas about western superiority.
answer: increase in population.

question: Government policy was an important part of early industrialization for all of the following reasons EXCEPT?:
option: railroad building.
the stabilization of the currency.
social welfare programs for workers.
the reduction of trade barriers.
laws benefiting business organization.
answer: social welfare programs for workers.

question: According the the Classical Economists\' "Iron Law of Wages"?:
option: if a worker received more than a subsistence wage, he/she would breed more children who would eat up the surplus.
with every rise in production, wages must also rise.
once workers\' wages fell below the level needed for subsistence, they would strike.
every wage increase must automatically benefit the employer, since additional purchasing power would be created.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: if a worker received more than a subsistence wage, he/she would breed more children who would eat up the surplus.

question: Which of the following was the major purpose of the Corn Laws in Britain in the early 1800s?:
option: to lower the price on grain imported from the rest of Europe.
to weaken the political power of the middle class in Parliament.
to improve the production and the quality of grain produced in Great Britain.
to cooperate with other grain producers in western Europe.
to protect the interests of British grain producers.
answer: to protect the interests of British grain producers.

question: One reason why the factory system replaced the domestic system in England was that?:
option: the decline of the guilds sharply reduced the amount of skilled labor.
women no longer had time to give to their families or to do the domestic work around their homes.
there was a marked decrease in the labor supply.
neither water power nor steam power could be used efficiently in the home.
Parliament passed laws designed to weaken the domestic system.
answer: neither water power nor steam power could be used efficiently in the home.

question: The Industrial Revolution in Britain was in a large part inspired by?:
option: the urgent need to solve great urban poverty.
the failure of the cottage industry system.
entrepreneuers who sought and accepted new manufacturing methods and inventions.
the great industrial success of the century before in Holland and France.
kings who controlled patents for new inventions.
answer: entrepreneuers who sought and accepted new manufacturing methods and inventions.

question: Which of the following is TRUE of changes in the standard of living in the first half of the 19c?:
option: there is not complete agreement on this question among historians.
the middle and upper classes made spectacular advances.
while real wages were higher than before, few workers were permanently employed.
some skilled workers were noticeably better off.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: The Industrial Revolution began in England for all of the following reasons EXCEPT?:
option: England had ample capital for investment.
she was an island nation safe from invasion.
an abundant source of power was available.
the government had created a business-friendly climate.
she had the necessary conditions for a factory system.
answer: she was an island nation safe from invasion.

question: The Luddites?:
option: physically attacked machines they believed adversely affected their livelihood.
were the first movement of the working classes on the continent.
were the lowest of unskilled workers in England.
received little support from the people in their areas of activities.
were English coal miners protesting harsh conditions.
answer: physically attacked machines they believed adversely affected their livelihood.

question: The conclusions of Malthus and Ricardo relative to economic affairs suggested that?:
option: capitalism and a free society would eventually abolish poverty and suffering from the world.
only social reforms and strong government intervention in the economy could alleviate human misery.
liberals were right to reject government interference in economic affairs because it could do no good.
economics is too complex a subject to be understood in rational or scientific terms.
poverty was caused by a lack of education and could be remedied by mandatory elementary school attendance.
answer: liberals were right to reject government interference in economic affairs because it could do no good.

question: Robert Owen\'s only success was the?:
option: establishment of New Harmony in Indiana as a successful experiment.
organization of consumers\' cooperatives.
winning of widespread support for his economic theories.
organizing of powerful trade unions.
passage of the Peoples\' Charter in Parliament in the 1830s.
answer: organization of consumers\' cooperatives.

question: The Enclosure Movement in England had all but which one of the following features?:
option: former common grazing lands were fenced in.
small farm holding were consolidated into large agricultural units.
wool production declined as food crops became more profitable.
many peasants were put off the land.
it resulted in the passage by Parliament of the Corn Laws.
answer: wool production declined as food crops became more profitable.

question: In England, the Factory Act of 1833 clearly?:
option: limited the hours of work for children under thirteen years of age.
forbade work for girls under 18 years of age.
expanded a factory owner\'s ability to hire children under the age of 12.
stated that children under 13 years of age should not be permitted to enter the work force.
forbade women from working more than 12 hours per day in the textile mills.
answer: limited the hours of work for children under thirteen years of age.

question: The New Poor Law did which of the following?:
option: abolished the workhouse.
tried in spite of great difficulties to keep families together.
required the poor to work in the workhouse for a maximum of two years only.
provided a government welfare payment for the head of each household of one pound a month until he became employed.
established unpleasant workhouses in the hopes that only the truly needy would seek public assistance.
answer: established unpleasant workhouses in the hopes that only the truly needy would seek public assistance.

question: Classical liberals supported all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: freedom of the press and of assembly.
written constitutions.
free trade.
universal male suffrage.
parliamentary or representative institutions.
answer: universal male suffrage.

question: During the century following 1832, the MAIN objective of the Reform Acts passed by the British Parliament was the?:
option: establishement of the right of trial by jury.
extension of suffrage.
restriction on the King\'s power.
increase of protective tariffs.
elimination of all press censorship.
answer: extension of suffrage.

question: The group that gained most political power as a result of the Reform Bill of 1832 was the?:
option: landed aristocracy.
poor living in the workhouses.
farm laborers.
middle-class people of the towns.
factory workers.
answer: middle-class people of the towns.

question: Despite little immediate success with their reform demands, the Chartists saw all but which one of these demands passed into law?:
option: universal suffrage.
dropping of property qualifications for members of Parliament.
holding of annual elections for members of Parliament.
creation of more equal electoral districts.
secret ballot.
answer: holding of annual elections for members of Parliament.

question: Urbanization and industrialization in 19c Europe?:
option: created new social classes.
increased class conflict.
changed family life.
influenced the creation of the Realist school of art and writing.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: Mussolini won support for his Fascists by promoting his party as a bulwark against?:
option: liberal democracy.
syndicalism.
capitalism.
Bolshevism.
nationalism.
answer: Bolshevism.

question: Which of the following groups composed the "Popular Front" in France during the 1930s?:
option: liberals and conservatives.
socialists and communists.
fascists and communists.
peasants and workers.
clerics and royalists.
answer: socialists and communists.

question: The social group that was hit most severely by Germany\'s inflation in the 1920s was the?:
option: middle class.
farmers.
aristocracy.
industrialists.
factory workers.
answer: middle class.

question: Catholicism was recognized as the sole religion of Italy by the?:
option: Dawes Plan.
Lateran Accords.
Locarno Treaty.
Council of Constance.
Kellogg-Briand Pact.
answer: Lateran Accords.

question: In a totalitarian state?:
option: the state controls every aspect of the lives of its people.
all industry is owned by the government
a complete revolution occurs every 20 years.
the state guarantees civil liberties to its wealthy citizens.
the government is based upon ministerial responsibility.
answer: the state controls every aspect of the lives of its people.

question: All of the following are true of women in Mussolini\'s Italy EXCEPT?:
option: they were urged to have more children.
they were not allowed to join the work force.
they were discouraged from using contraception.
they were given subsidies if they had large families.
they were discouraged from participating in the work force.
answer: they were not allowed to join the work force.

question: In the early 1920s, Germany\'s Weimar Republic was crippled by?:
option: the election of Adolf Hitler.
its close identification with fascist organizations.
the number of elderly people it had to subsidize.
a lack of political leadership.
the economic reversals of the Great Depression.
answer: a lack of political leadership.

question: In seizing and maintaining power in the 20th century, Communists, Fascists, and Nazis all?:
option: established good relations with churches.
respected existing treaties.
cooperated fully with the League of Nations.
blamed their nations\' troubles on scapegoats.
encouraged private economic enterprise.
answer: blamed their nations\' troubles on scapegoats.

question: Mussolini’s Fascist Party gained public support in post-war Italy by?:
option: working within the political system to elected to Parliament.
arguing that Italy had been slighted by the Allies at the Peace Conference.
taking advantage of labor unrest and directing violence against socialists.
appearing to align themselves with the rightful authority, the king.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: A major reason for the failure of the democratic government in Germany after World War I was the?:
option: failure of the government to solve Germany\'s economic problems.
threat of a communist revolution.
war destruction of German farms and factories.
illiteracy of the masses.
threat of attack from neighboring nations.
answer: failure of the government to solve Germany\'s economic problems.

question: Which of the following did NOT contribute to Mussolini\'s rise to power?:
option: support of strong wealthy landowners and industrialists.
nationalists demand that Italy should receive more territory from the Versailles Treaty.
a growing number of disgruntled World War I veterans.
peasant unrest in the countryside of Italy from 1919 to 1922.
severe unemployment after the war.
answer: peasant unrest in the countryside of Italy from 1919 to 1922.

question: The  fasces  or bundle of rods with an ax was a symbol that Mussolini\'s party derived from?:
option: ancient Egypt.
Alexander the Great.
the Great Seal of the United States.
Nazi Germany.
ancient Rome.
answer: ancient Rome.

question: The program of the British Labor party in the post-World War I period may be described or characterized as?:
option: Fabian socialist.
conservative.
reactionary.
Marxist.
laissez-faire capitalist.
answer: Fabian socialist.

question: The European country hardest hit by unemployment during the Great Depression was?:
option: the Soviet Union.
Germany.
France.
Italy.
Great Britain.
answer: Germany.

question: The British economist John Maynard Keynes became famous during the depression of the 1930s because he?:
option: argued that the only cure for the Great Depression was socialism.
said that the western democracies should adapt Soviet-style five-year plans.
argued that if private investment funds were idol, government funds must be employed to encourage economic activity and to increase purchasing power.
encouraged governments to balance their budgets so that interest rates would go down and private enterprise could borrow more easily.
called for huge tax cuts to encourage consumer spending.
answer: argued that if private investment funds were idol, government funds must be employed to encourage economic activity and to increase purchasing power.

question: Neville Chamberlain\'s promise of "Peace in our time" referred to?:
option: success in negotiations over war reparations.
the agreement at Rapallo.
the effectiveness of the League of Nations in the Ethiopian crisis.
success of the appeasement policy at Munich.
the Kellogg-Briand Peace pact.
answer: success of the appeasement policy at Munich.

question: During the inter-war years, the history of Europe supports the generalization that?:
option: the policy of appeasement was successful.
the League of Nations successfully checked aggression.
European nations gave up their African colonies.
economic distress contributed to the rise of fascism.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: economic distress contributed to the rise of fascism.

question: The Spanish Civil War became an international issue because?:
option: the Popular Front was a coalition government.
Spanish troops invaded France.
the king of Spain was tried and executed in the World Court at the Hague.
Britain and France sent money and war materials to the Loyalists.
Italy and Germany sent troops and arms to fascists in Spain.
answer: Italy and Germany sent troops and arms to fascists in Spain.

question: The Hitler-Stalin Pact contained an agreement for?:
option: both to partition Poland.
the Soviet Union to take Turkey.
both to divide territory in the Middle East.
the Germans to invade England by sea in early 1940 and for the Soviets to overrun Iraq and take the British oil fields there.
both to declare war against France and Great Britain.
answer: both to partition Poland.

question: France in the 1920s and 1930s?:
option: had the most modern military technology in Europe.
was willing to give back Alsace-Lorraine to Germany if the Germans continued paying their World War I reparations more quickly.
experienced a time of political discord and military conservatism.
was no longer concerned with reparations of the threat of another war with Germany.
suffered more than other countries from the Depression.
answer: experienced a time of political discord and military conservatism.

question: One reason for the failure of the peace movement between World War I and World War II was the?:
option: invention of the atomic bomb.
the long period of prosperity throughout the world.
conflict between members of the Triple Alliance and the Triple Entente.
absence of an international court of justice.
weakness of the League of Nations.
answer: weakness of the League of Nations.

question: One characteristic of 20c authoritarian regimes was that they were generally?:
option: imposed by terror rather than elections.
popular with their people.
the most technologically advanced countries.
put into power by foreign occupation.
unpopular and short lived.
answer: popular with their people.
