question: One of the most obvious differences between realistic and romantic writers was the fact that?:
option: realists glorified common people and actions by making them seem extraordinary.
romantics were uninterested in nature because it was an obvious part of reality.
realists rejected poetry as a proper way of expressing the real world and preferred the novel instead.
romantics were interested in the inner mind, whereas realists rejected psychological themes.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: realists rejected poetry as a proper way of expressing the real world and preferred the novel instead.

question: Nietzsche\'s criticism of Christianity was aimed primarily at?:
option: the Christian belief in miracles and other doctrines that are not based on reason.
Christian morality, which he believed was repressive and fit only for slaves.
Christianity\'s rejection of science and the rational thought of the Enlightenment.
the corruption and abuses that had occurred throughout the history of the church.
the ideals expressed by Pope Leo XIII in his encyclical,  Rerum Novarum .
answer: Christian morality, which he believed was repressive and fit only for slaves.

question: Which of the following was the greatest single contribution to medicine in Europe in the 1870s?:
option: research on contagion and infectious disorders.
establishment of government supported health agencies.
isolation of the smallpox virus and vaccine.
provision of infant care reducing mortality rates.
development of medical and health insurance.
answer: research on contagion and infectious disorders.

question: The experiments Pavlov conducted with dogs showed the importance of?:
option: arbitrary interpretations.
animal psychology.
natural selection.
conditioned responses.
subjective reflexes.
answer: conditioned responses.

question: Emmeline Pankhurst was noted for her?:
option: realistic novels depicting the life of poor workers.
impressionist paintings.
militant advocacy of women\'s suffrage.
contributions to the field of science and medicine.
leadership in the pacifist movement.
answer: militant advocacy of women\'s suffrage.

question: The "demographic transition" that took place between 1870 and 1914 involved?:
option: a sharp rise in the death rate.
an increase in the birthrate.
a decrease in the size of the middle class in Western Europe.
movement from urban to rural areas.
a huge migration of Europeans to the United States, South America, and Australia.
answer: a huge migration of Europeans to the United States, South America, and Australia.

question: By 1900, the leading industrial power in Europe was?:
option: Germany.
France.
Italy.
Britain.
Belgium.
answer: Germany.

question: Sigmund Freud believed that the way to solve the conflicts of his psychologically disturbed patients was to?:
option: change that patient\'s id.
use electrotherapy along with drugs.
help them override the pleasure principle.
trace repression back to its childhood origins.
destroy their superegos.
answer: trace repression back to its childhood origins.

question: The positivists believed that?:
option: because society operates according to scientific laws, it can be understood, but not changed.
general rules of social behavior can be derived from the examination of empirical data.
human behavior is so diverse that it can be understood only through the application of pure reason.
religion should be abolished because it plays no part in satisfying basic human needs.
humans cannot change their behavior, so it is the role of a totalitarian state to impose law and order on society.
answer: general rules of social behavior can be derived from the examination of empirical data.

question: What view of Fabian socialists differed from orthodox Marxism?:
option: socialism was more likely to succeed in less industrial countries.
private property and socialism could co-exist.
democracy could lead to socialism, revolution was not necessary.
workers were not really able to run government and had to be taken care of by a paternalistic state.
only a brutal dictatorship could lead to a socialist society.
answer: democracy could lead to socialism, revolution was not necessary.

question: Kings in the Late Middle Ages increasingly had to consult representative assemblies to grant new taxes because?:
option: Of the breakdown of feudal mechanisms to collect taxes.
A decline in population after the Black Death required an expansion of the tax base.
Absolute kinship characteristic of High Middle Ages had declined in the late Middle Ages.
Income from ordinary revenues, particularly rents, had declined.
They needed approval to reinstate or increase traditional revenues.
answer: Income from ordinary revenues, particularly rents, had declined.

question: All of the following figures opposed the growing papal authority EXCEPT?:
option: Marsilius of Padua.
Bernard of Clairvoix.
William of Ockham.
John Huss.
John Wycliffe.
answer: Bernard of Clairvoix.

question: The instability of the 14c was the result of the?:
option: weakening of feudalism in Europe.
increasing financial pressures on European rulers.
demographic turmoil caused by the Black Plague.
widespread failure of European rulers to produce direct male heirs.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: The Great Schism was finally resolved?:
option: by the Fourth Crusade against Constantinople.
when the pope in Avignon died.
by returning the pope to Rome, but Catholicism\'s political power was broken.
when the Holy Roman Emperor put his own candidate on the throne of Peter.
by the Fourth Crusade against Constantinople.
answer: by returning the pope to Rome, but Catholicism\'s political power was broken.

question: Which of the following statements most accurately describes the impact of the development of gunpowder on Europe\'s nobility?:
option: gunpowder led to the end of knights in armor and jousting with lances.
gunpowder was so scarce and expensive that only the nobles could afford to use it.
gunpowder had little effect on European warfare because early weapons were so primitive as to be virtually useless.
gunpowder allowed kings to wage war against the nobles and subdue them.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: gunpowder led to the end of knights in armor and jousting with lances.

question: Conciliarism?:
option: insisted that secular rulers had the right to appoint bishops.
demanded that a pope must call a church council every ten years.
argued that a general council of top church officials, not the pope, possessed supreme earthly authority in the church.
championed the absolute power of the pope.
sought to reform the church by the formation of new orders of wandering friars.
answer: argued that a general council of top church officials, not the pope, possessed supreme earthly authority in the church.

question: All of the following trends occurred in the decades after the outbreak of the bubonic plague in 1348 EXCEPT a?:
option: fall in land values and rents.
rise in real wages.
reduction in the total land area under cultivation.
downward trend in the prices of manufactured goods.
decline in the demand for grain.
answer: downward trend in the prices of manufactured goods.

question: One of the most important consequences of the Hundred Years\' War was that?:
option: England and France entered an extended period of peace and solidarity.
French armies ravaged England.
Parliament widened its powers in France.
both England and France began to tax the clergy.
Parliament widened its powers in England.
answer: Parliament widened its powers in England.

question: Unam Sanctam  expressed which of the following views?:
option: temporal power was subject to the spiritual power of the church.
the Conciliar Movement was unjust.
the power of the church was subject to the power of the monarch.
Joan of Arc was a heretic.
only one pope could serve as head of the church.
answer: temporal power was subject to the spiritual power of the church.

question: The Hanseatic League monopolized trade in the?:
option: Mediterranean Sea.
English Channel.
Baltic and North Seas.
Hanse Sea.
Adriatic and Black Seas.
answer: Baltic and North Seas.

question: Christians were forbidden to loan money at interest because?:
option: the Alfonsine Table included profits from interest on bills of exchange.
money could not make money.
maritime insurance rates already included profits from interest.
limited partnerships made it illegal.
according to canon law, only Italian banks, such as the Medici, could charge interest.
answer: money could not make money.

question: What was the purpose of the English Navigation Acts?:
option: to halt the Triangle Trade between Britain and the New World.
to require colonial goods to be shipped to England in English ships.
to secure a trade treaty with the French over the sale of slaves.
to provide for the discovery of new routes to Asia.
to end the lucrative smuggling business along the shores of northern Ireland.
answer: to require colonial goods to be shipped to England in English ships.

question: A most significant result of the Seven Years\' War was the?:
option: loss of the French Empire in America.
end of religious warfare in Europe.
the partition of Poland between Russian and Austria.
a peace treaty between France and Austria.
a truce between Spain and France.
answer: loss of the French Empire in America.

question: All of the following are true of 18c British mercantilism EXCEPT?:
option: encouragement of staple-crop production in America.
requirement that trade between Britain and the colonies be carried in British or American ships.
prohibition on the importation of certain items from non-British sources into the colonies.
encouragement of local manufacturing in her colonies.
requirement that items imported into the colonies be shipped through Britain first.
answer: encouragement of local manufacturing in her colonies.

question: The economic theory of mercantilism would be consistent with which of the following statements?:
option: economies will prosper most when trade is restricted as little as possible.
colonies are of little economic importance to the mother country.
a government should seek to direct the economy so as to maximize exports.
it is vital that a country import more than it exports.
tariff barriers should be avoided as much as possible.
answer: a government should seek to direct the economy so as to maximize exports.

question: Which of the following statements concerning late 18c farming is most accurate?:
option: changes in the climate resulted in a colder and wetter period in European farming.
market agriculture was gradually replacing subsistence agriculture in most parts of Europe.
despite increases in productivity, the number of acres under production in Russia, Prussia, and Hungary were actually decreasing.
technical improvement in farming spread rapidly among almost all European farmers.
agricultural production increased because animal husbandry was abandoned in favor of grain production.
answer: market agriculture was gradually replacing subsistence agriculture in most parts of Europe.

question: From the European perspective, the principal outcome of the Seven Years\' War was the?:
option: continuing Anglo-French colonial rivalry.
containment of British involvement on the Continent.
end of Sweden as a great power.
recognition of Dutch independence.
subsequent struggle between Prussia and Austria for hegemony in Central Europe.
answer: subsequent struggle between Prussia and Austria for hegemony in Central Europe.

question: Which of the following resulted from British mercantilist policies?:
option: a reduction of exports to the Continent.
British colonists no longer purchasing all of their goods from Britain.
a serious decline of Dutch shipping and commerce.
the abolition of British tariffs and import taxes.
a decline of trade with colonial plantation owners.
answer: a serious decline of Dutch shipping and commerce.

question: The economic policy of  laissez-faire ?:
option: contends that individuals should be allowed to pursue their own economic interests.
argues that all must contribute to the good of the society in order for it to remain economically viable.
sets out a series of governmental controls over individual economic pursuits.
focuses on regulation on the local level to shape economic growth.
argues that strict economic controls should serve as the basis for the economic system.
answer: contends that individuals should be allowed to pursue their own economic interests.

question: The English South Sea Bubble Crisis of the early 18c involved?:
option: a political struggle between Puritans and monarchists.
the economic collapse of a government monopoly and a speculative scheme.
a rise in the price of agricultural land.
controversy resulting from gold stolen from Spanish ships.
a period of religious fervor.
answer: the economic collapse of a government monopoly and a speculative scheme.

question: Which of the following nations acquired territory in Asia in the 18c through the initiative of agents working for joint-stock companies?:
option: France and Great Britain.
the Netherlands and France.
Spain and the Netherlands.
Prussia and Austria-Hungary.
Great Britain and the Netherlands.
answer: Great Britain and the Netherlands.

question: Which of the following applies to the early development of industrialization in Europe?:
option: the steam engine fueled industrial development during the late 1600s.
there was almost no industrial or proto-industrial activity in Europe before the end of the 1700s.
a period of proto-industrialization during the 1600s and 1700s preceded the Industrial Revolution.
European industrialization was hindered by the rise of capitalism.
initiative on the part of the aristocracy was chiefly responsible for Europe\'s early industrialization.
answer: a period of proto-industrialization during the 1600s and 1700s preceded the Industrial Revolution.

question: Which of the following is characteristic of 18c economic change?:
option: decreased world trade.
the decline of the factory style of textile production.
the creation of more common lands and open fields for production.
the increase in both population and food supply.
the absence of globalization.
answer: the increase in both population and food supply.

question: India eventually came under the control of the British crown because of?:
option: a military victory over the Dutch in the mid-seventeenth century.
the financial and administrative successes of the British East India Company.
Lord Macartney, who used Boers to quell local rebellions.
King James I, who granted colonists their first charter.
Prime Minister Robert Clive, who led Parliament to support the move.
answer: the financial and administrative successes of the British East India Company.

question: Jethro Tull\'s discoveries were part of a general movement to?:
option: make the potato the staple of the Irish diet.
enclose land and push small farmers off their holdings.
promote the planting of traditional European crops.
apply the principles of scientific experiment to agricultural practices.
improve the breeding practices of livestock in Scotland.
answer: apply the principles of scientific experiment to agricultural practices.

question: The agricultural improvements of the mid-18c were based on the elimination of?:
option: livestock farming.
the open-field system.
rotation of fields.
most agricultural pests.
nitrogen-producing plants, such as peas and beans.
answer: the open-field system.

question: Adam Smith\'s economic theory advocated?:
option: government intervention in order to control the flow of bullion through extensive tariff systems.
the use of a controlled money supply as a means of limiting inflation.
that governments avoid regulation in favor of the operation of individual initiative and market forces.
the institution of state-controlled guilds to fix standards of production and wages.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: that governments avoid regulation in favor of the operation of individual initiative and market forces.

question: Proto-Industrialization refers to?:
option: the employment of laborers who worked at home but in a capitalist system dependent on urban merchants.
the development of the rural factory system.
improvements in machinery and labor relations.
the development of systems of transportation and communication necessary for full industrialization.
the strictly agricultural economy that preceded the Industrial Revolution.
answer: the employment of laborers who worked at home but in a capitalist system dependent on urban merchants.

question: What was the nature of trade between eastern and western Europe in the 17c ad early 18c?:
option: western Europe imported grain in increasing amounts from eastern Europe in return for art objects and manufactured goods.
eastern and western Europe remained economically isolated, as Russia, Poland, and Prussia extended their trade relationships with the Ottoman Empire.
the inability of eastern Europe to produce anything of value to the West frustrated attempts to establish trading connections between the two halves of Europe.
eastern Europe emerged as a powerful challenger to Western domination of the global commercial network.
eastern European merchants began to compete with western European economic interests in the Middle East and in Africa.
answer: western Europe imported grain in increasing amounts from eastern Europe in return for art objects and manufactured goods.

question: Adam Smith\'s phrase "invisible hand" referred to which of the following?:
option: the universality of manual labor prior to the Industrial Revolution.
the automatic mechanism of a free economy.
the power harnessed by Watt\'s steam engine.
the control over economic activity exerted by mercantilistic legislation.
God\'s presence in the economic world.
answer: the automatic mechanism of a free economy.

question: As First Consul, Napoleon combined what he conceived to be the best of the Revolution and of the old regime. This led to all of the following reforms EXCEPT?:
option: careers in government service were determined by talent, not pedigree.
the creation of the Bank of France.
the codification of French law.
equal rights for women.
the establishment of a solid currency and public credit.
answer: equal rights for women.

question: Napoleon\'s Concordat with the Papacy contained all but one of the following provisions?:
option: Catholicism was to be the "preferred" religion of France.
primary education was to be controlled by the clergy.
the state had the power to regulate the place of the church in French society.
non-Catholics were to enjoy religious freedom.
lands confiscated and sold during the Revolution were to be returned to the church.
answer: lands confiscated and sold during the Revolution were to be returned to the church.

question: The most persistent opponent of Napoleon and the French Republic was?:
option: the royalists.
the United States.
Great Britain.
the Russian-Austrian alliance.
the Jacobins.
answer: Great Britain.

question: Under the Napoleonic Code, workers received?:
option: no specific rights or guarantees.
the right to organize unions but not strike.
the right to boycott employers who would not bargain collectively.
the right to organize unions and strike.
the right to organize unions but not bargain collectively.
answer: no specific rights or guarantees.

question: All of the following are true about the Napoleonic Era (1799-1814) EXCEPT?:
option: Napoleon came nearer than anyone before or since to imposing political unity on the European continent.
Europe was transformed, not only through resistance to Napoleon but through collaboration in his reforms.
the fighting during the period amounted to a world war, involving not only Europe but America.
despite the fact that all the other European great powers, England, Prussia, Austria, and Russia, were allied against him from 1799 onwards, Napoleon managed to defeat them until 1812.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: despite the fact that all the other European great powers, England, Prussia, Austria, and Russia, were allied against him from 1799 onwards, Napoleon managed to defeat them until 1812.

question: A lasting effect of the Napoleonic occupation of Europe was the?:
option: the decline of Russian military power.
stimulation of national feeling in the subject lands.
collapse of international trade.
formation of a  Entente Cordiale  to keep the peace.
sudden end of any social or economic reforms.
answer: stimulation of national feeling in the subject lands.

question: Which of the following was achieved during the regime of Napoleon Bonaparte?:
option: he codified the laws of France in his famous Civil Code.
women\'s legal position was weakened with the activation of the Civil Code.
he arranged a Concordat with the Catholic Church.
he created a powerful, centralized bureaucracy.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: Although the French Revolution had abolished slavery, Napoleon?:
option: found that it still survived in some French colonies.
got Spain to give French merchants the  asiento  power to sell slaves in Central America.
decided to reinstate it and ordered the invasion of Haiti and capture of Toussaint-Louverture.
wanted to go further and grant voting rights to former slaves.
successfully reconquered Haiti and restored slavery.
answer: decided to reinstate it and ordered the invasion of Haiti and capture of Toussaint-Louverture.

question: Napoleon was seen by some as an heir of the Revolution because of his?:
option: commitment to equality of opportunity.
support of local elections.
promotion of freedom of expression.
commitment to parliamentary government.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: commitment to equality of opportunity.

question: Napoleon\'s purpose in instituting the Continental System was to?:
option: defeat England through economic war.
consolidate the separate states of Germany.
unify Italy.
create a united Europe under the leadership of France.
punish Russia for his il-fated invasion.
answer: defeat England through economic war.

question: In general, Napoleon championed?:
option: political freedom but not social equality.
the restoration of the  Ancien Regime .
all the rights of citizenship proclaimed by the National Assembly.
equality under the law but not political freedom.
freedom of expression but only for the aristocracy.
answer: equality under the law but not political freedom.

question: Why is it significant that Napoleon crowned himself as emperor of the First French Empire in 1804?:
option: he was the first of his line.
it was a symbolic gesture to show his independence.
because of the Concordat of 1801, the clergy refused to participate.
it had no significance.
because the Senate had named him "Emperor of the French" rather than "Emperor of France."
answer: it was a symbolic gesture to show his independence.

question: What was the direct cause of the rebellions in Latin America in the first part of the 19c?:
option: slave revolt in Haiti.
the American Revolution.
the French Revolution.
the spread of Enlightenment ideas.
Napoleon\'s invasion of Spain.
answer: Napoleon\'s invasion of Spain.

question: The Quadruple Alliance included all of the following European powers EXCEPT?:
option: Britain.
Austria.
Prussia.
Italy.
Russia.
answer: Italy.

question: Napoleon?:
option: was born and raised in Paris.
joined the Jacobins shortly after the French Revolution.
won a naval victory over Horatio Nelson off the coast of Egypt.
had poor math skills.
won the Battle of Trafalgar.
answer: joined the Jacobins shortly after the French Revolution.

question: Napoleon\'s conquest of Spain doomed its American empire by?:
option: draining precious resources away from colonial economies for the French war machine.
opening Spanish America up to British invasion.
allowing the colonies to govern themselves for six years.
killing off nearly all trained Spanish administrators.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: allowing the colonies to govern themselves for six years.

question: How did Napoleon deal with the Holy Roman Empire?:
option: he replaced the empire with the Confederation of the Rhine.
he annexed the southwestern states to France and created a Northern German Confederation under the leadership of his brother.
he expanded the empire\'s control over the Confederation of the Rhine.
he crowned himself Holy Roman Emperor.
he installed his own candidate as Holy Roman Emperor.
answer: he replaced the empire with the Confederation of the Rhine.

question: After the French Revolution and the Napoleonic era, France?:
option: became a socialist state.
completely revised its legal system.
instituted universal suffrage and education.
was divided into departments rather than provinces.
rejected the possibility of a constitutional monarchy.
answer: was divided into departments rather than provinces.

question: Which country was NOT ruled by a member of the Bonaparte family during the first decade of the 19c?:
option: Holland.
Westphalia.
Poland.
Spain.
Prussia.
answer: Prussia.

question: The rule of the British East India Company in India was terminated as a result of?:
option: the Crimean War.
reorganization of the British Empire by Disraeli.
The Congress of Berlin in 1885.
the Sepoy Mutiny.
the ambitions of Queen Victoria.
answer: the Sepoy Mutiny.

question: Great Britain exported opium to China in order to?:
option: demoralize Chinese resistance to conquest.
find a means of paying for imports from China.
goad the Chinese into war with Britain.
overcome other European trade rivals.
increase profits for British merchants in Egypt.
answer: find a means of paying for imports from China.

question: In arguing for the positive effects of her imperialist rule in India, Britain could point to all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: a competant civil service which generally served well in India.
an increase in education including instruction in English.
eradication of discrimination based on caste.
development of the Indian infrastructure.
control of hostilities among diverse Indian religious groups.
answer: eradication of discrimination based on caste.

question: Which of the following is the BEST reason for the beginnings of late 19c imperialism?:
option: the need to develop manufacturing in non-industrialized nations.
the global competition of European nations for claims to less developed areas.
missionary activities to proselytize and convert the heathens.
the acquisition of territories promising strategic benefit.
national security and the need for an international balance of power.
answer: national security and the need for an international balance of power.

question: Extraterritoriality and treaty ports were?:
option: legal agreements between France and Britain.
rights granted by the East India Company to native Indians.
features of the "unequal treaties" China was forced to accept.
imposed on Russia after her defeat in the Crimean War.
concessions made by the United States to the Hawaiians in the 1880s.
answer: features of the "unequal treaties" China was forced to accept.

question: Colonial rivalries that helped to increase international tensions before World War I included?:
option: British and French conflicts with Germany over Morocco.
Serbian hostility to Russia.
German-Russian conflicts in Africa.
Dutch-British clashes in the East Indies.
United States ambitions in Puerto Rico.
answer: British and French conflicts with Germany over Morocco.

question: A unique feature of the "new imperialism" was the?:
option: reliance on indirect political control over colonies through ruling native elites.
establishment of European control over Latin America.
establishment of direct political control over colonies through elaborate imperial bureaucracies.
decline in number of Western countries building empires.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: establishment of direct political control over colonies through elaborate imperial bureaucracies.

question: Which of the following did NOT occur at the Berlin Conference of 1884-1885?:
option: It was determined that nations claiming territories in Africa would have to demonstrate the creation of a real presence calculated to produce economic development.
The Congo was yielded to Leopold of Belgium as the Congo Free State.
The conference laid the ground rules for all further acquisitions in Africa.
The conference divided all of Africa among the major European powers.
The conference organized and structured the terms under which Africa would fall to European nations.
answer: The conference divided all of Africa among the major European powers.

question: One striking difference between the British and the French imperial models in Africa is that?:
option: the British preferred to use local institutions to control subject populations.
the French preferred to employ local rulers to govern their colonies.
many more British citizens relocated to Africa to administer their colonies than did French citizens.
the British actively sought to convert Africans to Christianity while the French did not.
the British established schools and academies to train African civil servants to run their colonies, while the French did not.
answer: the British preferred to use local institutions to control subject populations.

question: Which of the following are considered causes for the "new imperialism"?:
option: a search for markets for European manufactured goods.
European racism.
acquisition of colonies for prestige and national security.
missionary zeal.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: Which of the following statements concerning the internal economies of the European colonies is most accurate?:
option: the introduction of European technology, such as railways and telegraphs, was intended to improve the internal economies of the colonies.
slowly the industrial system of the West, including factories and the production of manufactured goods, was introduced into Africa and Asia.
by 1914, Asian and African colonies had won economic independence from the European colonizers.
the internal economies remained separate from the trade with Europe, but continued to thrive.
colonial economies were steadily reduced to dependence on the European-dominated global market.
answer: colonial economies were steadily reduced to dependence on the European-dominated global market.

question: The 19c term "White Man\'s Burden" reflects the idea that?:
option: Asians and Africans were equal to Europeans.
Europeans had a responsibility to improve the lives of their colonial peoples.
imperialism was opposed by most European.
Asians and Africans would be grateful for European help.
democracy was the best form of government for Asia and Africa.
answer: Europeans had a responsibility to improve the lives of their colonial peoples.

question: Philip II strengthened the Spanish Inquisition in the Netherlands because?:
option: he wanted to expel Jews living in the Netherlands.
he wanted to find and punish Dutch Protestants.
he wanted to assist the Prince of Orange, William the Silent.
he wanted to investigate suspected witches from the Netherlands.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: he wanted to find and punish Dutch Protestants.

question: Elizabeth I\'s major goal in foreign policy was to?:
option: avoid open warfare whenever possible and keep England strong and at peace.
start rebellions against the Scots.
marry one of the available foreign kings or heirs to their thrones.
create a democratic republic in England.
go to war with France and recapture lands lost by England during the Hundred Years\' War.
answer: avoid open warfare whenever possible and keep England strong and at peace.

question: The Spanish term  Reconquista  refers to which of the following?:
option: Spain\'s victory over the French in northern Italy.
the defeat of the Islamic states on the Iberian peninsula.
the long sought trade agreement with Portugal.
the beginnings of Habsburg rule in Spain.
the sailing of the Armada against England.
answer: the defeat of the Islamic states on the Iberian peninsula.

question: Machiavelli\'s  The Prince  was significant because?:
option: it became the "Bible of 20c dictators."
it was one of the first reality-based treatises on political behavior.
it was based primarily on empirical (hands-on) observation.
it was written with the goal of unifying Italy.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: After the United Provinces of the Netherlands won independence from Spain, their government could BEST be described as?:
option: a strong monarchy.
a centralized parliamentary system.
a weak union of strong provinces.
a democracy.
a military dictatorships.
answer: a weak union of strong provinces.

question: The single greatest cause of warfare between 1550 and 1650 was?:
option: economic competition.
disputes over constitutional issues.
international disputes over territory.
religious rivalries.
growing tensions between kings and nobles.
answer: religious rivalries.

question: All of the following were accomplishments of the Tudor monarchy EXCEPT?:
option: abolishing the Privy Council.
getting the most funds from their not very extensive inheritance.
putting an end to dynastic instability.
transforming England into a Protestant nation.
creation of a new level of peerage as a fund-raising tool.
answer: abolishing the Privy Council.

question: Machiavelli would most likely support a politician who would?:
option: govern his actions by moral considerations.
take actions to weaken the government and let the people govern.
manipulate people and use any means to gain power.
govern with the help of the church.
take a passive approach when dealing with problems.
answer: manipulate people and use any means to gain power.

question: Which of the following was NOT a foreign policy initiative of Philip II of Spain?:
option: an attempt to invade England.
an attempt to influence the succession to the French throne.
an attempt to clear the Mediterranean of Muslim navies.
an attempt to return the Lutheran areas of north Germany to the Catholic fold.
an attempt to combat the work of Calvinists in the Netherlands.
answer: an attempt to return the Lutheran areas of north Germany to the Catholic fold.

question: The Holy Roman Emperor was a weak title because?:
option: the Austrian Habsburgs controlled the throne.
it was an elected monarchy.
France was the power behind the throne.
the religious authority of the Emperor was superior to the political.
it was selected by the papacy.
answer: it was an elected monarchy.

question: Ferdinand and Isabella consolidated royal power in Spain by?:
option: creating a single political and governmental system for all their kingdoms.
eliminating the power and privileges of the great nobles.
appropriating a portion of church income.
obtaining from the papacy the right to make major ecclesiastical appointments in Spain.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: obtaining from the papacy the right to make major ecclesiastical appointments in Spain.

question: Which of the following statements BEST characterizes Elizabeth I\'s religious policy?:
option: a policy of moderation and compromise.
a new wave of persecution of Catholics in Ireland.
a continuation of the policies of Mary I.
an acceptance of fundamental Protestantism after Mary\'s repressive Catholicism.
a continuation of all of the policies of Edward VI.
answer: a policy of moderation and compromise.

question: Which of the following statements concerning economic agreements is NOT CORRECT?:
option: the International Monetary Fund was organized to provide small loans to the desperately poor (particularly women) in developing countries.
the Marshall Plan provided economic aid for the rebuilding of western Europe following World War II.
the European Economic Community was founded in response to the pressures of the Cold War
North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994 established a partnership involving the U. S., Canada, and Mexico.
OPEC created an oil cartel among oil-producing countries to set the price of oil.
answer: the International Monetary Fund was organized to provide small loans to the desperately poor (particularly women) in developing countries.

question: In mid-1991, war broke out in the former Yugoslavia when?:
option: Croatia applied for membership in N.A.T.O.
Bosnian Muslims attacked Serbians.
Serb armed forces carved out enclaves for Serb minorities in the republics of the former Yugoslavia.
Slovenia and Croatia massacred thousands of Serbs.
Croatian, Slovenian, and Bosnian forces attacked Serbia.
answer: Serb armed forces carved out enclaves for Serb minorities in the republics of the former Yugoslavia.

question: In 1991, members of the European Union drew up a plan for common policy, currency, and banking known as the?:
option: Helsinki Accords.
Maastrict Agreement.
NAFTA.
Chirac initiative.
Dunbarton Oaks Treaty.
answer: Maastrict Agreement.

question: Which of the following statements about the reunification of Germany is TRUE?:
option: West Germany suffered a dramatic economic depression.
East Germans staunchly opposed political and social reforms.
economic problems were minimal.
The Soviet Union paid the German government $15 billion for the ecological damage caused by decades of military dumping of major carcinogens.
East Germans suffered a loss of welfare benefits.
answer: East Germans suffered a loss of welfare benefits.

question: Why have so many violent clashes broken out between ethnic and religious groups in Central and Eastern Europe since the fall of Communism?:
option: the opening of Eastern Europe to a free market economy has promoted ferocious competition, and this has provoked ethnic hatred.
because under Communism, the different ethnic and religious groups were allowed complete freedom, but under the new governments they are repressed.
the Eastern Europeans have simply imitated the growing nationalism in Russia.
the Communist regimes suppressed or permitted only cultural expression of national ambitions, and now these have resurfaced.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: the Communist regimes suppressed or permitted only cultural expression of national ambitions, and now these have resurfaced.

question: In 1993, Czechoslovakia?:
option: joined both the EC and NATO.
split into the Czech Republic and Slovakia.
suffered a violent civil war.
allowed local autonomy for all ethnic minorities.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: split into the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

question: The Paris Accord of 1990 was a Europe-wide agreement to?:
option: affirm existing borders and reduce arms.
resume the cold war.
privatize the economies of Europe.
intensify anti-drug efforts.
bring about a settlement in Bosnia.
answer: affirm existing borders and reduce arms.

question: Which of the following was not a factor in the collapse of the communist governments of eastern Europe in 1989?:
option: the leadership of Yugoslavia in opposing the Soviet Union.
the defeat of the communist regimes in democratic elections.
Gorbachev’s announcement that the Soviet Union was withdrawing its financial and military support.
the efforts of the Solidarity movement in Poland.
the failure of communism to gain the support of indigenous populations.
answer: Gorbachev’s announcement that the Soviet Union was withdrawing its financial and military support.

question: Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the movement for European unity has been threatened by?:
option: problems of integrating poorer and less-developed areas.
religious minorities that have not benefitted from economic prosperity.
hostility of other nations toward domination of the German financial system.
inability to decide on how to deal with violence in Bosnia.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: The event which finally galvanized NATO action against the Bosnian Serbs was?:
option: Milosevic\'s ditching of his Bosnian Serv allies.
the discovery of ethnic cleansing policies.
the fear of Russian intervention on the Bosnian Serb side.
the slaughter of several thousand citizens in Srebrenica.
the invasion of Bosnia by elements of the regular Serbian army.
answer: the slaughter of several thousand citizens in Srebrenica.

question: The July Ordinances were repressive decrees issued by?:
option: Nicholas I of Russia.
Prince Metternich of Austria.
Queen Victoria of England.
Frederick William IV of Prussia.
Charles X of France.
answer: Charles X of France.

question: Metternich may have been a brilliant statesman, but he was particularly misguided in?:
option: thinking he could stop forces of nationalism and liberalism.
his attempt to keep legitimate dynasties from returning to power.
his failure to understand the need to balance power.
serving the Austrian monarchy and totally disregarding the interests of Europe.
his support of the 1848 revolutions in Italy.
answer: thinking he could stop forces of nationalism and liberalism.

question: The chief purpose of the Congress of Vienna was to?:
option: stimulate nationalism.
protect western Europe from autocratic Russia.
restore the Old Regime as far as possible.
preserve the basic reforms of the French Revolution.
make Poland an independent state.
answer: restore the Old Regime as far as possible.

question: In 1820, revolutionaries overthrew the governments of which two states?:
option: Portugal and Tuscany.
France and Spain.
Piedmont and Prussia.
Spain and Naples.
Poland and Russia.
answer: Spain and Naples.

question: The  Burschenschaften  was?:
option: a revolutionary society in Italy.
student societies in Germany who wanted to spread German nationalism.
an army used to crush revolutions in Germany.
a German newspaper calling for a liberal state.
a German religious society to crush Protestantism.
answer: student societies in Germany who wanted to spread German nationalism.

question: The major supports of post-Napoleonic conservatism were?:
option: Roman Catholicism, the middle class, and urban workers.
legitimate monarchs, the middle class, and peasants.
radical religious groups, city dwellers, and rural poor.
peasants, university students, and the urban poor.
legitimate monarchs, landed aristocrats, and the leaders of the established religions.
answer: legitimate monarchs, landed aristocrats, and the leaders of the established religions.

question: The principle of legitimacy at the Congress of Vienna meant the?:
option: restoration of monarchs previously dethroned by Napoleon.
extension of democracy.
establishment of equality before the law.
self-determination of peoples.
rewarding countries who helped to defeat Napoleon.
answer: restoration of monarchs previously dethroned by Napoleon.

question: What became known as the "Eastern Question" in European affairs was actually a reflection of the?:
option: war for Greek independence.
Polish resistence to Russian reform programs there.
weakness of the Ottoman Empire.
the desire on the part of France and England to establish a naval presence in the eastern Mediterranean.
European fear of Russia.
answer: weakness of the Ottoman Empire.

question: The Decembrist Revolt of 1825?:
option: was devised by middle class merchants to secure political and economic reforms.
was the first rebellion in modern Russian history whose instigators had specific political goals.
symbolized the yearnings of Russian liberals whose numbers were substantial.
succeeded because the Russian officer corps was able to coordinate their rebellion with the one in Greece.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: was the first rebellion in modern Russian history whose instigators had specific political goals.

question: Which of the following was the key aim of the British Corn Laws in the early 1800s?:
option: to export grain at cheaper prices to France.
to weaken the power of the middle class in finance and banking.
to improve the quality of British grain.
to protect the interests of British grain producers from foreign imports.
to set up a free trade zone among farmers in western Europe.
answer: to protect the interests of British grain producers from foreign imports.

question: All of the following are true of the Romantic movement in the early 19c EXCEPT?:
option: it sympathized with revolts against oppression.
it placed great emphasis upon the individual.
it called for social reform.
it instilled a reverence for nature.
it accepted the basic ideals of the Enlightenment  philosophes .
answer: it accepted the basic ideals of the Enlightenment  philosophes .

question: Following the death of Alexander I in 1825, Russia under Nicholas I became?:
option: a police state due to Nicholas\'s fear of revolution.
the most liberal of the European powers.
a major imperialist power with colonies in Asia and Africa.
a limited monarchy under the control of the Duma.
an industrial power following the abolition of serfdom.
answer: a police state due to Nicholas\'s fear of revolution.

question: Generally, the revolutions of 1848 resulted in?:
option: success for the liberal forces in Europe.
slow gains at first for the liberals, followed by complete realization of their goals.
the end of monarchy in Europe.
a consolidation of moderate, nationalistic middle classes.
the end of the age of romantic revolution.
answer: the end of the age of romantic revolution.

question: The foremost social group embracing liberalism was made up by?:
option: factory workers.
the industrial middle class.
radical aristocrats.
army officers.
the clergy.
answer: the industrial middle class.

question: The Frankfurt Assembly failed because?:
option: it endeavored to establish a radical rather than a liberal state.
it did not resolve the contradictions between liberalism and nationalism in the building of a German state.
the Prussian army quickly blocked its revolutionary efforts.
its refused to support Polish nationalism turned the Polish army against the Assembly.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: it did not resolve the contradictions between liberalism and nationalism in the building of a German state.

question: The revolution of 1848 in France resulted in?:
option: the continued rule of Louis-Philippe but with radical reforms.
new elections to the National Assembly, resulting in the dominance of the radical republicans.
Europe\'s first socialist state under the guidance of the National Workshops.
an authoritarian regime under Louis Napoleon Bonaparte.
a limited monarchy under the restored Bourbons.
answer: an authoritarian regime under Louis Napoleon Bonaparte.

question: Czar Nicholas I ruled Russia with a policy of?:
option: repression and spying.
religious toleration and political liberties.
political freedom for only the wealthy class.
cultural freedom but strict economic and political controls.
enlightened despotism.
answer: repression and spying.

question: The novelty of the "Concert of Europe" system was its recognition that?:
option: war had become too dangerous a luxury for Europe to afford.
France could not be eliminated from the map of Europe.
free trade was necessary for the economies of Europe to improve after the recessions following the Napoleonic Wars.
wars were useful only to obtain territory, not spread political change.
internal affairs were the concern solely of the affected country.
answer: war had become too dangerous a luxury for Europe to afford.

question: The main flaw of the Congress of Vienna settlement was that it?:
option: treated France too leniently.
excluded Spain from any territorial settlement.
refused to recognize the strength of nationalism and French revolutionary values and ideals.
went too far in adapting to the new political values that had appeared by 1815.
excluded France from joining any political alliance system after 1820.
answer: refused to recognize the strength of nationalism and French revolutionary values and ideals.

question: The most important symbol of Romanticism became the?:
option: unified society marching collectively to a better future.
desperate working class fighting for its freedom.
oppressed nationalities fighting for freedom.
isolated individual in heroic struggle.
idealic life of the yeoman farmer.
answer: isolated individual in heroic struggle.

question: Count Henri de Saint-Simon believed that?:
option: nature should be worshipped as a god.
sexual freedom was a necessary component of political freedom.
society should return to 17c norms.
ownership of private property was a crime.
the key to progress was proper social organization.
answer: the key to progress was proper social organization.

question: The Revolution of 1830 in France?:had no influence over the revolution in Poland.
option: benefited the upper middle class.
resulted from Louis XVIII\'s refusal to deny his theoretical absolute power.
established Louis Napoleon as the new emperor of France.
put the working class ina position of political supremacy.
had no influence over the revolution in Poland.
answer: benefited the upper middle class.

question: The Protocol of Troppau?:
option: permitted Russia and Prussia to build up their armies.
advocated intervention in Italian affairs.
permitted stable governments\' intervention into countries experiencing revolution for the purpose of restoring order.
dismantled the Concert of Europe.
required countries experiencing revolution to temporarily concede their authority to allied European powers.
answer: permitted stable governments\' intervention into countries experiencing revolution for the purpose of restoring order.

question: King Louis-Philippe was called France\'s bourgeois monarch for all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: he increased the number of voters.
he favored the extension of political power to the working class.
in public he dressed in the clothes of an industrialist.
his strongest supporters were upper middle class businessmen.
he introduced policies that favored the bourgeoisie.
answer: he favored the extension of political power to the working class.

question: Utopian socialism was built upon the idea that?:
option: strong states should direct national economies.
conservative economic principles foster social stability.
political reform was more important than economic reform.
competition among workers drives progress.
cooperative living might create a better environment for people.
answer: cooperative living might create a better environment for people.

question: * cujus regio, ejus religio.  		* reaffirmation of German nationalism. 		* limited to the recognition of Lutheranism and Catholicism. * resolved the conflict between German Protestants and Catholic princes         in the Holy Roman Empire.  All of the statements above describe the?:
option: Treaty of Westphalia.
Edict of Nantes.
Peace of Augsburg.
Treaty of Paris.
Edict of Worms.
answer: Peace of Augsburg.

question: Which of the following was the underlying cause of the other four?:
option: the end of unity in Western Christianity.
the Protestant Reformation.
religious conflicts evident in wars in the last half of the 17c.
the Great Schism characterized by the Avignon papacy and the struggle between Pope Boniface XVIII and the French king, Philip IV.
increase in lay education and spiritual reading.
answer: the Great Schism characterized by the Avignon papacy and the struggle between Pope Boniface XVIII and the French king, Philip IV.

question: By the end of the 16c, the Protestant Reformation had extended its influence to all of the following nations EXCEPT?:
option: the Holy Roman Empire.
Spain.
Sweden.
England.
Switzerland.
answer: Spain.

question: When the coin in the coffer rings, the soul from Purgatory springs.  This jingle was most likely spoken by?:
option: Johannes Tetzel.
Martin Luther.
John Calvin.
John Knox.
Sir Thomas More.
answer: Johannes Tetzel.

question: The Schmalkaldic War (1546-1547) was begun by?:
option: the Hapsburg to extend their empire.
Philip II of Spain to subdue the Netherlands.
Ivan III of Russia to extend his domains.
Henry IV of France to suppress the Huguenots.
Charles V to restore Catholicism to the Holy Roman Empire.
answer: Charles V to restore Catholicism to the Holy Roman Empire.

question: Calvinist laws prohibited?:
option: investments and profits.
dancing and gambling.
the mixing of church and state.
capital punishment.
education for women.
answer: dancing and gambling.

question: Ulrich Zwingli was responsible for the Protestant conversion of?:
option: the Netherlands.
France.
Switzerland.
Portugal.
Denmark.
answer: Switzerland.

question: The Diet of Worms was?:
option: an Imperial Council that Martin Luther refused to attend.
the site of a debate between Martin Luther and John Eck.
a meeting in which the German princes took the decision to defend Martin Luther in the face of threats by Charles V.
a Protestant Council whose aim was to unify the various Protestant sects.
an Imperial Council that ordered Martin Luther to recant and condemned him when he refused.
answer: an Imperial Council that ordered Martin Luther to recant and condemned him when he refused.

question: The Peace of Augsburg (1555)?:
option: allowed every individual in the Holy Roman Empire to choose between Lutheranism and Catholicism.
made Calvinism the official religion of the Holy Roman Empire.
subjected both the Catholic and Lutheran churches to complete state control.
permitted only the ruler of each state in the Empire to choose between Lutheranism and Catholicism.
granted only a few rights to the Anabaptists.
answer: permitted only the ruler of each state in the Empire to choose between Lutheranism and Catholicism.

question: All are not created on equal terms, but some are preordained to eternal life, others to eternal damnation; and, accordingly, as each has been created for one or the other of these ends, we say that he has been predestined to life or death.  This statement above reflects an essential view of?:
option: John Calvin.
Desiderius Erasmus.
Martin Luther.
Ulrich Zwingli.
Francois Rabelais.
answer: John Calvin.

question: Probably the most important reason for the popularity of Lutheranism among the Northern German princes was that it?:
option: attacked the idea of divinely established Papal authority.
it made Germany politically weaker.
taught salvation by good works.
placed considerable emphasis upon the Emperor.
raised doubts as to the effectiveness of the Roman Catholic sacraments.
answer: attacked the idea of divinely established Papal authority.

question: Martin Luther rejected which of the following?:
option: the priesthood of all believers
justification through faith alone
the Bible as the final authority of God\'s word
the spiritual life as superior to a secular life
financial payment for the remission of sins
answer: financial payment for the remission of sins

question: Which of the following is not considered a cause of the Protestant Reformation?:
option: northern Renaissance scholars\' interest in early biblical texts.
the reform decrees of the Council of Trent.
increased lay interest in purifying church practices.
nationalist movements in the German states of the Holy Roman Empire.
the taxing policies of the Roman Catholic Church.
answer: the reform decrees of the Council of Trent.

question: The Brethren of Common Life represent?:
option: the extent of Protestant conversions in Italy.
the intense religious scholarship in Swiss monasteries.
a typical response of the papacy to the Reformation.
an example of pre-Reformation popular piety.
the power and appeal of John Calvin\'s message.
answer: an example of pre-Reformation popular piety.

question: John Wycliffe and John Huss both appealed to the superiority of?:
option: the kings.
the Church Councils.
the Bible.
the Catholic clergy.
devotion to saints and their relics.
answer: the Bible.

question: Calvin insisted upon strict observance of moral laws because?:
option: moral behavior was an outward sign that the person was probably of the elect.
he saw no connection between moral law and salvation.
it was easier to govern people who accepted a moral law.
he believed that government could be dispensed with if moral laws were closely obeyed.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: moral behavior was an outward sign that the person was probably of the elect.

question: Many German peasants were attracted to Luther\'s ideas chiefly because they?:
option: thought that his principles would get them into heaven directly, without having to pass through purgatory.
believed he justified their refusal to pay tithes to the Roman Catholic Church.
hated the Church\'s practice of granting indulgences.
felt that he would side with them in their struggle against the nobility.
believed he supported their freedom from serfdom.
answer: believed he supported their freedom from serfdom.

question: Martin Luther believed that women should?:
option: manage the household economy.
be allowed to enter the priesthood.
pursue careers outside the home.
rule the household.
be equal in all things.
answer: rule the household.

question: A result of the Protestant Reformation of the 16c was the?:
option: establishment of state churches in England, Scotland, and northern Germany.
separation of Church and State in France.
development of a uniform set of Protestant beliefs.
collapse of the temporal and spiritual power of the Pope.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: establishment of state churches in England, Scotland, and northern Germany.

question: Calvinism was a theocratic religion because?:
option: it allowed complete freedom of worship.
it believed in predestination.
it recognized that the seven sacraments were all valid ways to achieve salvation.
it believed in simple worship, a sermon, prayers, and hymns.
it permitted only members of its Church to hold political office.
answer: it permitted only members of its Church to hold political office.

question: The official creed of Lutheranism was summed up in?:
option: The Freedom of a Christian Man.
the  Augsburg Confession.
Address to the Nobility of the German Nation.
The Baylonian Captivity of the Church.
A Handbook for the Christian Knight.
answer: the  Augsburg Confession.

question: The popular lay movements that most directly assailed the late medieval Church were the?:
option: Albigensians and Beghards.
Cathars and Donatists.
Donatists and Arians.
Lollards and Hussites.
Waldensians and Beguines.
answer: Lollards and Hussites.

question: The principal reason for the sale of indulgences by the Roman Catholic Church was the?:
option: desire to complete the building of the new St. Peter\'s in Rome.
wish of the Church to engage in greater missionary activity.
need for another Crusade.
desire to establish more universities to train better clergy.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: desire to complete the building of the new St. Peter\'s in Rome.

question: The Protestant Reformation?:
option: weakened civil authority.
prevented the growth of religious tolerance.
encouraged the movement for popular education.
prevented Catholicism from spreading outside Europe.
weaken the authority of national states.
answer: encouraged the movement for popular education.

question: The printing press helped the Reformation succeed for all of the following reasons EXCEPT?:
option: it allowed for the rapid dissemination of radical ideas.
it allowed Martin Luther to publish and disseminate his works.
it allowed the papacy to rapidly suppress Lutheranism.
it decreased the cost of reading materials and made them more affordable to the middle and lower classes.
it allowed Martin Luther to print his works in the vernacular.
answer: it allowed the papacy to rapidly suppress Lutheranism.

question: The Council of Trent was important because?:
option: it provided for a new system to elect the pope.
it called for acceptance of Lutheran principles.
it eliminated the use of the  Index of Prohibited Books.
it adopted a general attitude of ecumenicism.
it reaffirmed the traditional doctrines of the Catholic Church.
answer: it reaffirmed the traditional doctrines of the Catholic Church.

question: The Reformation in Germany resulted in?:
option: a unified German state.
political fragmentation.
Italian control of Austria.
secular freedom for the peasantry.
the abolition of Catholicism.
answer: political fragmentation.

question: The English Reformation was peculiar because the government broke with Rome?:
option: when there was no theological dispute between king and pope.
after the pope took the side of the nobility against the king.
after Catholic Spain attempted to invade England.
after it took the side of France in a political dispute.
after Protestantism had already come to dominate English religious life.
answer: when there was no theological dispute between king and pope.

question: England\'s break with the Roman church became official with the passage of the?:
option: Six Articles.
The  Ninety-Five Thesis.
Act of Succession.
Act of Supremacy.
Act of Toleration.
answer: Act of Supremacy.

question: Martin Luther intended his  Ninety-Five Theses? :
option: to lead to a break with the Roman Catholic Church.
to initiate a debate on the buying and selling of indulgences.
to undermine the authority of the papacy.
to justify the buying and selling of indulgences.
to denounce the  Book of Revelations  from the New Testament.
answer: to initiate a debate on the buying and selling of indulgences.

question: The Reformation influenced the development of the modern world primarily by?:
option: reducing the power of the state over the lives of ordinary people.
providing some justification for challenging the absolute authority of kings.
discouraging the growth of capitalism, which was criticized as being too worldly and materialistic.
believing in complete religious freedom for everyone.
forcing the Catholic Church to reform itself.
answer: providing some justification for challenging the absolute authority of kings.

question: The "Weber Thesis" attempted to explain the connections between the rise of Calvinism and the rise of?:
option: absolute monarchies.
Anglicanism.
Catholicism.
the nation-state.
capitalism.
answer: capitalism.

question: In Geneva, the Calvinists?:
option: were crushed by the Catholic troops of the Holy Roman Emperor.
reformed the city with little opposition from an enthusiastic populace.
imposed strict penalties for blasphemy and immoral behavior.
withdrew the Ecclesiastical Ordinances in 1541.
saw their reforms jeopardized by the execution of Savonarola.
answer: imposed strict penalties for blasphemy and immoral behavior.

question: The Elizabethan Settlement?:
option: established the Church of England.
returned England to the Roman Catholic Church.
offered religious toleration and protection to French Huguenots living in England.
made militant Calvinism the official religion of England.
reintroduced Catholicism but did not require loyalty to the pope.
answer: established the Church of England.

question: Which of the following supported Martin Luther?:
option: Holy Roman Emperor Charles V.
the papal ambassador (legate) in Germany.
Pope Leo X.
Prince Frederick III, the Elector of Saxony.
the head of his Augustinian order.
answer: Prince Frederick III, the Elector of Saxony.

question: Pope Paul III did all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: call the Council of Trent.
reorganize the Roman Inquisition.
begin the Counter-Reformation.
reconcile Catholicism with Protestantism at the Imperial Diet of Regensburg.
he did everyone of these things listed above.
answer: reconcile Catholicism with Protestantism at the Imperial Diet of Regensburg.

question: This religious order became the tool of the papacy in their crusade against the spread of Protestantism in Europe in the 16c?:
option: the Society of Jesus (Jesuits).
the Tridentines.
the Ursulines.
the Grey Franciscans.
the Brethren of the Common Life.
answer: the Society of Jesus (Jesuits).

question: Catholicism was recognized as the official religion of France but limited toleration was extended to Calvinists by the?:
option: Peace of Augsburg.
Edict of Nantes.
Peace of Westphalia.
Treaty of Tordesillas.
St. Bartolomew\'s Day Massacre.
answer: Edict of Nantes.

question: The religious climate of France prior to the French Wars of Religion was best characterized by?:
option: a nobility that was nearly 50% Huguenots.
a population split evenly between Huguenots and Catholics.
Catherine de Medici\'s complete suppression of Huguenots.
a poorly organized Huguenot opposition to a Catholic majority.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: a nobility that was nearly 50% Huguenots.

question: The remark attributed to the French king, Henry IV, that  Paris is worth a Mass , is usually interpreted to mean that he?:
option: put political necessities above personal beliefs.
was a particularly devout Catholic.
remained loyal to the Huguenot party.
supported the policies of the Catholic League.
was insensitive in regard to religious issues.
answer: put political necessities above personal beliefs.

question: In 16c and 17c Europe, the member of a community most likely to be accused of witchcraft was?:
option: a merchant.
a royal official.
the village priest.
an elderly, widowed woman.
a noblewoman.
answer: an elderly, widowed woman.

question: In the late 1620s and early 1630s, King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden played a key role in European affairs by?:
option: opposing the expansionist plans of Cardinal Richelieu of France.
acting as intermediary between Catholic and Lutheran governments.
leading a Protestant coalition against Catholic Europe.
allying with Habsburg Spain to challenge British sea power.
arguing that state interest should take precedence over religious loyalties.
answer: leading a Protestant coalition against Catholic Europe.

question: The Peace of Westphalia?:
option: reconfirmed the power and grandeur of the Holy Roman Empire.
gave Sweden new territories along the Baltic Sea coast.
ensured Protestant domination over all of Central Europe.
returned the Continent to the status quo as of 1618.
weakened the Holy Roman Empire.
answer: weakened the Holy Roman Empire.

question: The St. Bartholomew\'s Day Massacre?:
option: decimated the ranks of the Protestant leadership but failed to suppress the anti-Catholic movement in Europe.
was successful and led to the collapse of French Protestantism.
demonstrated that the Counter-Reformation in France was essentially a dynastic and class struggle.
was followed by an English effort to assist the Huguenots.
resulted directly in an English effort to assist the Catholics.
answer: decimated the ranks of the Protestant leadership but failed to suppress the anti-Catholic movement in Europe.

question: The Thirty Years\' War became primarily a political conflict during the?:
option: Danish phase.
Italian phase.
Swedish-French phase.
Bohemian phase.
Swedish phase.
answer: Swedish-French phase.

question: In general, which of the following MOST accurately reflects the state of Europe in 1648?:
option: the northwest of Europe was predominantly Protestant while the south was mostly Catholic.
Catholicism was triumphant everywhere in Europe.
Protestants were the majority population in every Western European country.
the Holy Roman Empire emerged as a completely Lutheran sphere of influence.
France lost in her struggle with the Habsburgs to become the dominant land power in Europe.
answer: the northwest of Europe was predominantly Protestant while the south was mostly Catholic.

question: All of the following were consequences of the Thirty Years\' War EXCEPT the?:
option: settlement of the religious wars between Catholics and Protestants in Germany.
depopulation and economic stagnation of Central Europe.
emergence of Russia as a great European power.
predominance of France in Europe.
decrease of the power of the Holy Roman Emperors.
answer: emergence of Russia as a great European power.

question: The Church\'s view of witchcraft was that?:
option: there was no such thing, since there was no supernatural power except that of God.
women were less involved in witchcraft than men because they inherited the spiritual grace of the Virgin Mary.
witchcraft was a heresy or a spiritual crime only, and was no business of the secular authorities.
witches must be put to death for the good of society, but they might achieve salvation if they recanted before execution.
none of these choices are correct.
answer: witches must be put to death for the good of society, but they might achieve salvation if they recanted before execution.

question: The rebellions that swept through Europe at the time of the Thirty Years\' War indirectly resulted in?:
option: a decline in the power of the European middle class.
a tremendous decline of wealth in Spain.
the end of serfdom in Eastern Europe.
a huge increase in eastern Mediterranean trade.
an increase in the power of the European monarchies.
answer: an increase in the power of the European monarchies.

question: Historians who argue that the Treaties of Westphalia mark the beginning of a new era in diplomatic history cite all of the following arguments EXCEPT?:
option: papal objections to the treaties were ignored and the treaties did not receive papal sanction.
the Austrian Habsburgs abandones their Spanish cousins.
the German territorial princes acquired the right to sign treaties and made war, except against the emperor and the empire.
Sweden emerged as one of the strongest powers in Europe.
the treaties laid the groundwork for the subsequent rise of Russia as a major Continental power.
answer: the treaties laid the groundwork for the subsequent rise of Russia as a major Continental power.

question: The mission of the Spanish Armada in 1588 was to?:
option: acquire territory in the Baltic area.
reunite the throne of Spain.
support the rebellion in the Netherlands.
replace Queen Elizabeth with a Catholic monarch.
form a naval alliance with France.
answer: replace Queen Elizabeth with a Catholic monarch.

question: The  Malleus Maleficarum ?:
option: for years was considered the standard handbook on witches.
gave details on how to gain a confession from a heretic.
was used by the Church to prove that witches did not really exist.
was written by John Calvin.
was used by Martin Luther to justify his view of salvation by faith alone.
answer: for years was considered the standard handbook on witches.

question: Following the Thirty Years\' War, what country became dominant in Europe?:
option: Sweden.
France.
Spain.
Germany.
Bohemia.
answer: France.

question: The 16c religious wars that had plagued France were largely ended with the?:
option: Edict of Nantes.
accession to the throne of Louis XI.
Treaty of Cateau-Cambresis.
massacre of St. Bartholomew\'s Day.
resolution of the Habsburg-Bourbon conflict by the Peace of Augsburg.
answer: Edict of Nantes.

question: Which of the following is TRUE of the Dutch Revolt?:
option: the nobleman, William of Orange, led the revolt.
the Dutch flooded their own lands to hamper the Spanish.
the war was both a political and a religious struggle.
the southern provinces pledged loyalty to Spain in exchange for compromises on certain issues.
all of these choices are correct.
answer: all of these choices are correct.

question: The word vernacular is used to describe?:
option: the structure of the human skeleton.
a type of crossbow used by British archers in the Hundred Years\' War.
the early printing press typesets.
the spoken language of an area.
a political plot against Medici rule in Florence.
answer: the spoken language of an area.

question: The dominant trend of government in Renaissance city-states in Italy was from?:
option: republicanism to despotism.
democracy to theocracy.
absolutism to democracy.
despotism to theocracy.
theocracy to democracy.
answer: republicanism to despotism.

question: Which of the following locations had the greatest influence on shaping the values of the Italian Renaissance?:
option: the manor of a nobleman.
the cottage of a serf.
the townhouse of an Italian merchant.
the manufacturing districts of an Italian city.
a Benedictine monastery.
answer: the townhouse of an Italian merchant.

question: He is sometimes called the "Father of Humanism?:"
option: Sir Thomas More.
Petrarch.
Boccaccio.
Pico della Mirandola.
Johannes Gutenberg.
answer: Petrarch.

question: Renaissance education was characterized by?:
option: emphasis on developing the "complete individual".
tendencies to criticize the Church and openly encourage religious revolt.
little attention to anything but academic pursuits.
a hesitancy to question old teachings.
support of the religious reforms initiated by Savonarola in Florence.
answer: emphasis on developing the "complete individual".

question: The favorite classical author of Renaissance scholars was?:
option: Virgil.
Homer.
Cicero.
Plato.
Euclid.
answer: Cicero.

question: Which of the following was NOT a characteristic of the Renaissance?:
option: reemphasis on the culture of antiquity.
search for balance and proportion in politics.
the development of a historical and critical view of the world.
strong anti-Christian sentiment.
confidence in human rationality.
answer: strong anti-Christian sentiment.

question: The early Renaissance humanists in Italy would have been MOST interested in?:
option: translating a portion of the Bible into the vernacular.
perfecting the Italian language.
ministering to the sick and other needy people.
analyzing the accounts of the debates of medieval scholastics.
finding an old Greek manuscript.
answer: finding an old Greek manuscript.

question: Castiglione, in his work,  The Courtier ?
option: provided a handbook for politicians.
suggested the proper social graces for a young Renaissance noble.
supported the power of the monarch.
condemned the Church.
insisted upon the complete equality of social classes.
answer: suggested the proper social graces for a young Renaissance noble.

question: The literary masterpiece that satirized the ideals of knighthood and chivalry was written by?:
option: Rabelais.
Erasmus.
Cervantes.
Castiglione.
Petrarch.
answer: Cervantes.

question: Renaissance courtiers were?:
option: people who worked for the Venetian Republic.
slaves of the  doge  of Venice.
people who served a prince in multiple political and administrative ways.
military leaders whose conquests spread the Renaissance to northern Europe.
people who served in the Vatican as papal pages.
answer: people who served a prince in multiple political and administrative ways.

question: Civic humanists?:
option: advocated active service to the city-state.
opposed the use of public funds to patronize artists.
supported a theocracy in Florence.
advocated a life of scholarly contemplation.
opposed the republican form of government.
answer: advocated active service to the city-state.

question: Northern humanists differed from their Italian predecessors?:
option: by concentrating on the ancient Greek authors.
in that they had no need for rich patrons to support their work.
in their focus on the textual reexamination of the Bible and the writings of the early Church Fathers.
by refusing to use the vernacular in their work.
in their interest in medieval history.
answer: in their focus on the textual reexamination of the Bible and the writings of the early Church Fathers.

question: Art and sciences are not cast in a mold, but are perfected by degrees, by often handling and polishing, as bears leisurely lick their cubs into form.  (Michel de Montaigne,  Works II. xii , 1533-1592)
option: skepticism concerning known or revealed truth.
atheism and his subsequent execution as a heretic.
scientific methodology concerning experimentation in the natural sciences.
relativism in reference to absolute good or evil.
enlightened despotism as the most desireable form of government.
answer: skepticism concerning known or revealed truth.

question: Mannerist art was characterized by?:
option: formality, balance, restraint.
emphasis on decorative design.
extravagant use of bright colors and abstract design.
distorted human figures and unnatural lighting effects.
simplicity in human figures similar to Gothic sculpture.
answer: distorted human figures and unnatural lighting effects.

question: According to Jacob Burckhardt, the Renaissance represented?:
option: the greatest period of economic recovery in the history of Western civilization.
a period of moral decline.
an era of tremendous graft and corruption in Italian government.
a distinct break from the Middle Ages.
none of these choices are correct
answer: a distinct break from the Middle Ages.

question: Pico della Mirandola\'s  Oration on the Dignity of Man  stated that?:
option: humans were fallen creatures, but regain their place by following God\'s will.
God gave humans free will so that they could choose to be earthly or spiritual creatures.
human beings were nothing more thn undifferentiated animals.
only through prayer and good works could man achieve his full potential.
humans were divine and destined to spiritual life.
answer: God gave humans free will so that they could choose to be earthly or spiritual creatures.

question: Liberal education in the Renaissance included all of the following EXCEPT?:
option: the study of military theory.
a stress on physical education.
the mastery of Greek and Latin.
the study of music.
the ability to write poetry and appreciate good works of art.
answer: the study of military theory.

question: Thomas More\'s  Utopia ?:
option: illustrated the northern humanists\' break with the Catholic church.
represented the high point of northern humanist thought.
led to his execution at the hands of Henry VIII.
presented a revolutionary social order based on communal living and property.
stressed that the end always justified the means in politics.
answer: presented a revolutionary social order based on communal living and property.

question: The Prince  argued that?:
option: a prince must always behave in a moral fashion.
the prince\'s highest obligation was to God.
the prince\'s highest obligation was the preservation of his state.
the prince must give one-half of his wealth to the poor and to the Church.
the prince\'s highest duty was the accumulation of personal wealth.
answer: the prince\'s highest obligation was the preservation of his state.

question: Italian Renaissance art can be most appropriately described as?:
option: a revolt against the classical style and the advancement of a new artistic standard based on humanism.
NeoClassicism in which the traditional characteristics of harmony and symmetry were valued.
characterized by the spectacular and the deliberately nonsymmetrical.
romantic idealism predicated upon notions of secular fantasy.
the triumph of symbolism.
answer: NeoClassicism in which the traditional characteristics of harmony and symmetry were valued.

question: Lorenzo Valla gained fame for?:
option: becoming ruler of the Renaissance city of Florence.
his inventions.
challenging the authority of Voltaire.
proving the Donation of Constantine a fraud.
helping to unify Italy.
answer: proving the Donation of Constantine a fraud.

question: Construed as an intellectual threat to the Church, Humanism?:
option: argued that the episcopal order of the Roman church should be altered.
condemned the Church for not addressing the needs of the poor.
identified with the "New Science," which the Church opposed.
challenged papal supremacy.
maintained that the true source of authority within the Church was scripture.
